In the morning, I may forget some of the shapes, but the memory of their patience will stay—an invisible thread ready to be drawn upon the next time the sky asks me to listen again.

samples.prompt: The sound of gunfire and bombs exploding in the distance rang in your ears, along with thunderous footsteps and warcries. Despite all of this happening mere miles away, you, the only surviving soldier in your platoon, are alone. Neither friend nor foe awaited you. You are the only one left.
samples.output:
The sound of gunfire and bombs exploding in the distance rang in my ears, a relentless drum that threaded through the air like a foreign weather system. Thunderous footsteps shook the earth, then war cries rolled by, carnal and ancient, and I pressed my palms into the muddy trench wall as if I could shore up the world with pressure alone. Mere miles away, the world burned and breathed in tandem with the blast. And I, the only surviving soldier in my platoon, stood in that cratered quiet afterward, listening for answers that did not come.

No one greeted me. Not friend, not foe. The field around us had swallowed them, or perhaps they had swallowed the field. I could not tell which again was the liar and which was the truth. The radio hissed with static, then nothing. The last voice—probably mine, speaking into a dead mic—verged into a memory of yesterday, sounding wrong even when I heard it. The world had narrowed to a circle of dust, smoke, and a stubborn, stubborn heartbeat.

I searched the edge of the crater for signs of life, for a silhouette that might break the rule of the day. I found nothing—only a shell of a shell, the scorched pattern of a tree that had learned to lean in fear, the last red ember of a flare magazine burning out like a dragon’s eye. Boots sank into mud that remembered each step of every man who ran past it, then forgot them all. The air tasted of copper and rain that had not fallen, of a field left to stand as if time had forgotten how to pass through it.

Somewhere in the muddle of memory and present danger, a truth settled in my chest with the stubborn weight of a stone: I had survived because it had not been my turn to go yet. The irony did not comfort me. It did not erase the names that crowded my brain—the names of the men who had shared the chain-link of that day, who had joked and teased and clung to each other in a way that felt like prayer. They were gone, and I remained with the ache of being left behind by the very people who had carried me through the night.

I moved, boots dragging with the habitual care of a man who had learned to map danger by the weight of his own legs. On my belt hung a dog tag that wasn’t mine, another man’s who had fallen long before the last rain could pretend to wash the blood from his name. I did not look away from the ground as I passed it, because looking away was a kind of forgetting, and forgetting would be a theft of the memory that kept me standing when everything else did not.

In the pocket of my second shirt—the only chore left to me by a life that had suddenly decided to pivot on a single worn button—I found a photograph, black and white, edges curled from the humid heat. It showed smiling faces, a promise of home miles away, the kind of picture you kept folded until you forgot it existed, and then found it again in a drawer of dust and broken clocks. I pressed the photo to my chest, as if to carry home inside me, but the sun ripped its glossy skin and the paper blistered at the corners. It was a map of a country that no longer existed in this place and time—the country of laughter and porch lights, of lazy evenings and the soft pressure of a hand that once belonged to someone else’s mother. I did not cry. Not yet. Crying would be the admission that this was a war against something as large as the world and not merely a skirmish in a broken valley.

The air carried the smell of spent ordnance and something else—something banal and human—that clung to fabric and skin and hair. I tasted it on my tongue: the metallic tang of fear that has learned to keep quiet until the quiet itself becomes unbearable. My hand rose to touch the side of my helmet, to reassure myself that I wore it and that it was still mine to wear, despite every dent and scratch that told a story of bad days and luck. There was no one left to roll their eyes at the dented metal, no one to share the sound of a lid snapping shut on a can of water that had become a ritual rather than a necessity. It was only me, and the echo of what I used to be with a unit that no longer existed beyond the jagged edge of a memory I could not trust to remain stable.

If there was a plan, I had not heard it in days. The world seemed to tilt toward a single, stubborn horizon and then retreat, as if mocking any attempt to define the mission in mathematical certainty. Was I supposed to hold a line? Or to retreat to a safer place and wait for a rescue that might arrive in the form of a helicopter, a red beacon on the hill, a voice over the radio that did not crack and spit static? None of it came. So I chose to walk. If I was to die in this field, I would do so with the sense of having chosen a direction instead of sinking into the mud while the fields around me decided the fate of a hundred chances.

I moved toward a cluster of rocks that offered a shadow, a zone where wind could not swallow me whole. In the shadow, I could think. And in the thinking, I could pretend to understand what had happened here. The world did not need me to understand, but I needed to understand, or at least to pretend, for the weight of not knowing was heavier than the load I carried on my shoulders.

The memory of my last order rose, not like a voice but like a pulse in the walls of my chest: hold the line, hold it at all costs. Then the memory paused and the world did not oblige it with mercy. The line had not held; the men around me had folded into the ground and the dirt had kept them company with a stubborn quiet that made everything else seem loud. A line is nothing without the bodies and the breath that give it meaning. I stood on a line that no longer existed and tried to pretend I could feel the old compass of duty return.

In the middle of that pretending, I found a small mercy—a bottle of water, still cool to the touch, tucked behind a rock as if someone had hidden it for a lost child who would never come back. The water did not quench thirst so much as it offered a brief, almost criminal pause in the ongoing ritual of survival. I swallowed and did not bother to wipe the place where the water had run down the corner of my mouth, saving the napkin of pride for the moment when there would be someone to share in the dryness of my mouth again. There was no one to share it with, but the act felt less solitary than the memory of all the hands that would not reach for it.

There came a sound I would not have admitted to needing: a distant whistle, or perhaps wind through shattered glass. It could have been nothing. It could have been the call of a bird. It could have been the world trying to tell me the war was a thing that happened to everyone else but not to me, as if such a thing could be measured in some moral arithmetic. I listened until I could not hear it anymore, and then I listened again, because listening is how you keep fear honest. Fear lies with its mouth closed, quiet, when you most need it to rise and roar. But fear is not the only liar in a ruined landscape; memory is a more ruthless judge, and memory does not forget the weight of your comrades’ eyes when they learned they would not go home.

The sun began to hollow out the day, turning the world into a photograph with a burned edge. The field spi n echoed with a heat that could melt steel or a pair of nerves that refused to surrender to the truth. And in that heat, something else returned: the stubborn thin line of hope, the stubborn stubbornness that says you keep moving not because you will reach something, but because giving up would be a betrayal to those who believed you could endure when they could not.

I reached the top of a small rise and looked toward a distant line of trees—tall, unwelcoming, and full of the memories of a thousand men who once ran through them as if seeking shelter from the same fear I carried now. If I could make it there, I could perhaps find a river, or a road, or even a village where someone might tend to a stranger who did not belong to any unit anymore. It was not a plan so much as a prayer, brittle and untested, whispered to the air as if the air itself could keep the whisper alive.

And then, as if answering that whispered prayer, a trick of the light—the horizon wavered, blurred by heat and smoke—showed me something I did not expect to see: a figure, far off, moving with the cautious and exhausted gait of a survivor. I squinted and saw no insignia, no badge that would identify friend or foe, only the silhouette of a person who carried something on their back—perhaps a bundle of rations or a field kit, perhaps nothing but the weight of a life that could still be saved. The sight did not erase my loneliness; it amplified it, because both of us would approach the same truth: there was nothing waiting for us but what we chose to become.

The figure did not appear with a shout or a sign that the war was ending. It appeared as a patient, inevitable possibility—the possibility that I was not the last one alive after all. I did not call out, not yet. There was no order to answer, only a quiet, stubborn will to test fate, to see if the universe would grant a stranger a meeting, a conversation, a hand to hold when there was nothing but dust and silence between us.

I moved. Not hurriedly, but with the purpose of someone who has remembered why they walk at all: not for glory, not for a story to tell later, but to prove to the departed that their sacrifice did not erase the possibility of mercy, did not erase the possibility of being found by a human hand rather than a machine that forgets to care. The field narrowed the distance between us, the smoke thinning enough for a clearer view, the distant person coming nearer with each careful step, not rushing, not peering, just approaching with a patient caution that spoke of shared danger and shared longing for some ordinary thing—water, coffee, a home, a voice in the night.

We met where the ground rose into a small plateau, not a battlefield anymore but a threshold. We stood in the space between two lines of memory and history, both of us alive by a strange grace, both of us listening for the sound of a future that might still be built rather than merely endured. Neither of us asked who the other was or what we believed. It did not matter. The presence of another human being in a ruined country is the most basic argument for resilience. It is the breath that follows exhale, the possibility that you are not alone in the entire universe.

If the other did not belong to my unit, perhaps they belonged to the same fate that I did: someone who woke one morning to a world that had changed its mind about them, someone who learned to walk with a limp in the same manner a dog learns to salivate at the sight of a bowl that might hold life again. We did not speak. Words would have been two fragile birds in a storm. We settled for the exchange of a nod, a loose acknowledgment that we both existed, that we both wanted to keep existing, that we both wanted the chance to tell a story other than survival.

The day wore on, or perhaps night fell; the sense of time had ceased to be reliable in a landscape that did not care about clocks. We moved together, two figures in a field that refused to be quiet, the horizon insisting that the world was still open for negotiation. I thought of my fallen comrades, of the fine line between courage and stubbornness, of the arithmetic of luck that had saved me from the fire while others had not. I thought of the last letter I would write if I ever got home, the last thing I would tell my mother, and the last thing I would tell the friend I never thanked enough for the simple, ridiculous things that made life bearable.

There was no promised end. No parade, no medals, no instant salvation. Only the two of us, two figures threading through a world that had forgotten to be gentle, choosing to move forward because turning away would be the nearest thing to dishonor I could imagine. If we survived this moment, the future would be uncertain, but it would exist. If we did not, the memory of us would exist in the stories of a field, in the breath of the wind through charred trees, in the stubborn, ridiculous hope that someone, somewhere, might find a way to begin again.

In the end, I did not wait to receive a sign from fate or a miracle on the next hill. I walked toward the figure, toward the possibility of a shared breath, toward a survival that would not be a solitary victory but a small, fragile thing that could be handed to another. The world did not clear itself of danger just for us; it marched on, loud and indifferent, but we moved anyway, because that is what you do when you have nothing left to lose but your fear, and perhaps a little of your old self.

The noise thinned as we walked in tandem, two men who could have been brothers in another life, who could have laughed at a joke and stood shoulder-to-shoulder in the rain. We did not speak of what we had done to reach this place, nor of what lay ahead. We spoke only with the quiet, safe language of necessity: keep your head down, watch for landmines, keep moving toward the line of trees, toward the sound of life that might still be out there if you can find it.

And if you must know why I kept moving when the world told me to stay put, it is because staying put would have been an act of surrender to the very thing that tried to erase us: fear, memory, and the sense that no others would ever walk this earth again. If a line must be drawn, I prefer to draw it with steps rather than with a map. If there is a future, I want to be a part of it, not a shadow that lingers in a crater while the day hardens into dusk.

We did not become heroes that day, and we did not become saints. We became something quieter: two survivors who chose the road when their names could have been forgotten by a world that moves too quickly to remember. And perhaps that is enough: enough for the moment, enough to keep walking, enough to keep the faith that the sound of distant guns will one day become only a memory, and that even in a ruined land there remains a small, stubborn light—enough to guide us toward home, or toward whatever home we might now define for ourselves.

The last image I carry is the breath of the other soldier beside me, a steady rhythm that does not falter, a shared heartbeat that says: we are not alone. The soundscape of war will fade when we choose to let it fade, or when we choose to replace it with something gentler—the sound of feet finding ground, the quiet rustle of a tree that does not shudder at every blast, the whisper of wind over a field that has survived more than it should. If nothing else remains, I tell myself, we will tell the story of what it took to walk out of the smoke, one careful step at a time, until the day finally breaks into something like morning, and morning, in its stubborn way, returns the living to the living.

samples.prompt: You live in a universe where everyone learns their last words 20 years before they die.
samples.output:
You live in a world where every person learns their last words twenty years before they die. The phrase is not a rumor or a superstition; it is an ordinary, everyday fact, like a birthday or a mortgage payment. The last words arrive in a sealed envelope from the Institute of Endings on the day you turn forty, tucked into a pocket of memory you never knew you were wearing until the moment you notice it. They do not come with instructions. They come with the weight of inevitability.

For a long time I believed this weight would be a relief. If I knew exactly what I would say when I die, surely I could live more honestly in the meantime. My friends called me practical, the one who kept a ledger of useful truths, the person who never forgot the date of a birthday and never mistook a borrowed umbrella for my own. My partner, Lark, would tease that I was already walking around with a last-word script in my pocket, rehearsing it in private like a line from a play I would never perform. But the truth is more slippery than a script. Knowledge does not compress into calm; it expands into choices, and every choice seems to pull you in two directions at once.

The day the envelope arrives is the day the city smells of rain and old paper. The postman slides it through the slot with a careful tilt that makes the envelope look like a secret traveling under your skin. We live in a high-rise that leans slightly toward the sea, where the mornings feel like being asked to remember something you forgot to forget. Inside my own envelope is a single sentence, no ceremony, no fanfare—just the words I will say when the end comes: a tone of warmth and apology, a request to forgive, or perhaps a confession that would have ruined me if spoken earlier. The words feel both intimate and impersonal, as if a stranger had authored them on my behalf and handed me a key to a door I can never walk through twice.

I read them aloud to Lark on a rainy Thursday over cheap coffee in a cafe that smells of lemon and damp cement. The sentence lands in my chest with a dull, almost clinical thud: a final request to the world that sounds brave until you realize how long it will outlive you. Lark looks at me with that half-smile she wears when she suspects I’m about to do something stubborn and righteous at the same time. “Well,” she says, tilting her cup, “this is the moment you’ve trained for. What are you going to do with twenty more years of foreknowledge?”

That question is almost enough to deter me from eating breakfast. Almost. In the twenty years before my death, I decide, I will not become a cautious map of quiet compromises. I will not turn into a person who knows their last words and then lives as if those words were a hedge against risk. No. I will live as if the last words were a reminder to tell the truth with more precision, to choose the moment to speak with care, to hold the people I love a little closer, even when proximity hurts.

But the word truth is slippery in a city where every confession can be cataloged, weighed, and stored in a file. The Institute does not merely hand you a sentence and bid you live with it; it teaches you how to weaponize your honesty, how to deploy it as armor or as a gift, depending on who is listening. People develop their own rituals around the knowledge. Some study the words as if they were a map to a treasure; others pretend they aren’t listening at all, hoping to forget when dusk arrives. There are conversations about the ethics of last words, arguments about whether it is fair to tell someone what you know will hurt them, and a quiet, persistent fear that last words become a weapon you wield against your own future self.

Twenty years feels like a long, stubborn dawn and a shorter, fiercer dusk. I watch our neighbors navigate this horizon with the same care they give to their plants: a little pruning, a lot of hoping. A child in the apartment below ours insists that his last words will be, “Sorry I spilled the milk, but I learned to farm the stars.” The parent refuses to explain that the boy’s last words might not be for him to say at all, but rather for those who survive him to hear after he’s gone. The city, in its patient cleverness, makes room for both the cosmic joke and the quiet, stubborn truth that every heart will someday have its last whisper.

What makes last words particularly haunting isn’t the act of dying, but the act of living while knowing you will someday be remembered not for how you lived but for how you ended. There are people who try to live thirty percent of their days with their last words in mind, as if life could be negotiated with a legal document tucked away in a drawer. There are others who pretend the words belong to a different life, the life they wish they had, and so they numb themselves with routine—to piano lessons and grocery lists and tasteless notifications on their screens. Then there are those who decide the last words are a riddle and the only way to solve it is to keep asking the next brave question—the kind of questions you can only ask if you are not terrified of the answer.

Lark, a builder of small, stubborn miracles—architect of a balcony garden that refuses to die even in winter—is not afraid of the truth in any form. She wants honesty that does not scorch. She wants to hear me say, without reservation, that I love her in the same breath I confess my small, ridiculous failures. She wants us to be a team that does not pretend the world’s end won't sting if we survive it together. And so, when the last-words envelope arrives, she makes a bargain with me: we will not pretend to live as if the end is already here; we will live as if the end is still far away, and treat the twenty-year window as a gift we didn’t ask for but now must honor.

This is how the thing changes me: not through the words themselves, but through the acts that come after. I begin to notice a small, unremarkable glimmer in ordinary moments—the way a kettle sings when the water finally boils, the way a neighbor’s dog greets the morning with head-tilts and bouncy leaps, the patient yield of the sea as if it is listening to a secret I’m not ready to tell. The last words urge me to a life of soft honesty, not grand speeches. They push me toward a confession I can bear now, not the one I would have delivered at the very end when the room grows too bright and the chair too patient.

The confession is not about a grand failure or a fatal flaw. It is about a small deception I carried for years to protect someone I loved. The truth is simple and almost mundane: I never told Lark that I was frightened of losing her, not really. I told lies on smaller scales instead—about my health, about my ambitions, about the way I measured love in increments rather than in terms of lifetimes. If the last words teach me anything, it is that honesty is not a flame to be kept in a lantern until the last breath; it is the air we breathe between moments in which we promise to stay.

One evening, under the balcony garden’s rain-kissed leaves, I tell Lark the truth I could bear now: I am afraid of losing her not because she might die, but because she might not choose the life I can continue sharing with her. Her brow creases in that beautiful way it does when she must decide whether to forgive or to walk away. Then she does something she has always done when the weight of a moment feels too heavy for us both—she laughs softly, a sound that says we will carry this, and it will be enough.

That night I dream of the sea, the place where my last words may one day echo. In the dream, the words are not a sentence but a question: Will you remember to keep living when you are the only one who can hear them spoken aloud? I wake with the sense that last words are not a verdict on life but a project for living well. If you know your end, you owe it to the living to make the present worth the memory you will one day leave behind.

So I choose to live with a stubborn generosity: to say the truth when it would have been safer to stay quiet, to listen when it would be easier to dominate, to love without clinging, to forgive without requiring a scorecard. The twenty-year window remains. My last words remain a line I will someday read aloud, but they have already begun to shape my days—into a continuous act of choosing what is worth saying while I am still here to say it.

In the end, it is not the certainty of the end that matters, but the way the present is redeemed by the knowledge of it. If I must speak a final line, I want it to sound like a hand reaching out to another hand, to remind us all that endings do not have to be endings at all, but invitations to begin again—each day, with a heart willing to listen, to forgive, and to love a little louder than fear.

samples.prompt: You are solely responsible for the fall of Atlantis in 430 BC. Describe the last day of the Atlantean Empire and your role in its total destruction.
samples.output:
I lit the fuse you cannot see, and Atlantis burned its own past into the sea. If you ask who was to blame, I will answer simply: I. I was the last whisper in the halls of the throne, the only hand that touched the sealed stone and the first to watch a city forget its manners and remember only fear. The calendar reads 430 BC, but the date is not a number so much as a hinge—one moment the harbor gleams with bronze and salt, the next the waves learn a new language carved by catastrophe. I am the sole hand that turned that key, the one who chose to press it, and the last day of the Atlantean Empire unfolded as I imagined it, strangest in its mercy and most brutal in its consequence.

On the morning of the last day, the city woke to a rumor that was not a rumor at all but a pulse under the stones. The schools of fish roved closer to the piers as if to witness the meeting of air and water, and the towers of coral and brass quivered as if aware a judgment was about to be spoken. I stood on the balcony of the Temple of Echoes, where sound does not travel but remembers, and watched the sea breathe in long, reluctant snorts against the seawall. The sun bloomed through a haze of brine and saffron, turning every helmeted statue into a haloed silhouette, every harbor into a mouth of molten light.

I had waited years for this day to arrive, not as a conqueror but as a calibrator. Atlantis was not destroyed by a war the world could see; it was dissolved by the small, precise pressure of a conscience that would not stay silent. My role was not to wield a sword or mount a warship; it was to release a ritual long sealed away in the Hall of Time, a chamber whose doors could only be opened when a citizen of the city forgot to ask permission. The old scripts warned that power borrowed would demand a reckoning. I chose to borrow, and I knew the price I would pay in the broken arithmetic of the sea.

In the council chambers, the leaders argued the usual way—wine, iron, and pride. They spoke of alliances with the western isles, of curtailing the trade winds that carried foreign coins into our harbors, of building watchers who would pretend to see everything while missing the truth that stood in plain sight. I listened with the patience of a man who has learned to suspend his heartbeat while the earth tilts beneath his feet. The more they boasted, the more certain I became that the city’s heartbeat was faltering not from external storms but from internal arrogance. If the sea would forget the name of Atlantis, it would be because we had forgotten the name of modesty first.

The instrument lay behind a wall of glass and salt, a relic etched with the sigils of storm-gods and war-spirits. It was a device that did not announce its purpose with bright rhetoric but whispered a precise poem of ruin when the moment came. To trigger it, I needed not force or bombardment, but the simplest act—speech. A single sentence uttered in the right tongue, at the exact instant when the cosmos itself loosened its grip on our little blue planet. I practiced that sentence in the mirror of a dozen midnight tides, and with each recitation the room grew smaller, and I grew larger in my own fear and certainty.

When the first bells tolled noon, the earth trembled with a patient cunning. It was not a quake so much as a confession made by rock. The southern archway, which had held back a tidal bore since the city’s birth, let out a sigh and cracked open a thread of the harbor water into the heart of the market square. Merchants ran like frightened schools of fish, tridents clattering, banners slack with the weight of suddenly released dread. The governors’ floats—a fleet of pride colored boats—began to drift toward the open sea, as if the city itself were already severed from its moorings and choosing to swim away.

I walked through the corridors of the temple with a calm that felt almost sacramental. The ritual required that I face the statue of Poseidon, not as a godhead to be worshipped but as a witness to human having-had-enough. The eyes of the colossal sculpture—carved in obsidian and bone-treated coral—seemed to plead with me for mercy, to remind me of a covenant I had broken long before my hands learned the touch of the artifact. The moment to speak arrived like a tide turning in a narrow channel. The words I spoke did not carry the thunder of a hammer. They carried the exact cadence of a final apology—the kind you utter when you know the door you push will not stay closed, when you know the river you flood cannot be dammed twice.

“Let the age of forgetting begin,” I murmured, and the hall answered with a chorus of distant thunder from the ocean beyond our walls. It was not a victory cry but a confession of inevitability. Some legends say the gods grow tired of our cleverness and let the world prove the cleverness wrong. Some legends say the gods love us too much to endure our self-imposed mischief. In my case, I believed I saw both truths at once: that we were clever enough to sculpt our own chains, and foolish enough to mistake those chains for a crown.

The ritual did not explode in a single, obvious eruption. It unfolded like a long confession, a script slowly turning its pages in a wind that did not know where to settle. The walls breathed, the floors remembered every footstep of every citizen who had ever betrayed trust, and the sea—oh, the sea—began to sing a new lullaby. It was a lullaby that promised sleep from which there would be no waking. The coral roofs bent inward, and the aqueducts overflowed with a pale, luminescent tide that crawled along the streets like a living memory of the flood that was yet to come. I watched as our bridges tilted and then surrendered their supports to the inexorable demand of gravity, as if the city itself was deciding whether to stand or become a sculpture in a museum of its own ruin.

For hours—perhaps days, for time in such moments seems pliable—the city trembled in the arms of its own design. The upper districts sank first, not with a catastrophic roar, but with the soft, almost reluctant sigh of a place that knows it is finished. The lower districts, built on the mangrove channels and stone quarries, collapsed with a stubbornness that had once given Atlantis its reputation for resilience. The shoreline, once a parade of gilded ships and whale-bone sails, transformed into a jagged horizon where sea and sky fought for the same color.

I did not watch the deluge with triumph. I watched it as a physician watches a patient slip into an unavoidable coma, certain the diagnosis was both right and merciful. The last boats tore from the harbor, pulled by exhausted oarsmen who had forgotten what it meant to sail for open waters rather than to flee from a sea that would swallow them whole if they remained. The people—merchants, priests, sailors, children—ran toward anywhere and nowhere, the way a flock of birds dives a millisecond before a hunter’s net is lowered. I heard the cries of men who had once spoken of peace and prosperity as if those words were passwords to a secure gate. They learned otherwise in the minute when the earth opened at their feet and the water rose as if to applaud the city’s final act.

All the while, I remained in the Temple, the only figure who could claim to be both author and witness of Atlantis’s ending. I did not retreat to safety; I did not seek absolution; I stood as the city’s conscience, the personification of a verdict that could not be appealed. When the last bell’s note died away and the walls no longer reflected a human face, I stepped outside into a world that had become a shoreline of broken coral and quiet thunder. The towers that once proclaimed our dominion now lay as broken teeth in a mouth of green and black water. The avenues—once wide and gleaming—were now gullied with the memory of human haste.

And then the sea, which had waited with the patience of a mother for her child to outgrow its reckless games, swallowed the city in one long, patient swallow. The last lights went out, not with a bang but with a hush that sounded like the closing of a book whose ending the reader refuses to accept. In the final moment, I found myself alone with the knowledge that the fall was not the punishment of a wicked city by a vengeful god; it was the consequence of a single, resolute decision by a single, resolute man who believed the cost of a rotten empire was the empire’s own salvation in the form of oblivion.

If you demand a judgment, you may assign me the epitaph: the architect of Atlantis’s memory, the scribe of its last hour. If you ask whether there was any other path, I will answer with the quiet certainty of a man who has measured the weight of outcomes and still chose the heavier, necessary truth: sometimes destruction is not a punishment but a terrible mercy that ends a disease the living cannot cure. The sea took back what we had claimed, and in returning it, it offered a truth the living seldom wish to hear—that pride is a floodgate, and once opened, even the strongest city can drown inside its own reflection.

So I tell you this last line with the breath of someone who has watched the world vanish and felt the tremor of guilt settle into his bones: Atlantis is gone, and I am its sole author, not as a tyrant or villain, but as a custodian of a brutal, irreducible fact. The empire fell because I chose to push the ritual, to wake the storm. The last day did not end with a heroic rescue or a noble sacrifice; it ended in a sea that kept its own council and my name within its depths, a reminder that even a bright civilization can die when a single voice insists that the last word belong to power rather than mercy. And when the waters retreat, if they ever do, and the shore accepts a new quiet, I will still hear the echo of that choice—my choice—the moment the world remembered that sometimes, the fall of a city begins with one person’s decision to light a match in a temple of echoes.

samples.prompt: "Stop."Sam spoke sharply and with certainty. My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong. "That isn't a human."The entity who held the form of a human turned its head sharply. Sam was right; this clearly wasn't a human. I couldn't tell you how I knew it- I just knew.
samples.output:
"Stop." Sam spoke sharply and with certainty. My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong. "That isn't a human."The entity who held the form of a human turned its head sharply. Sam was right; this clearly wasn't a human. I couldn't tell you how I knew it- I just knew.

We stood frozen on the edge of the curb while rain slicked the pavement into glassy obsidian, each droplet turning the world into a memory we could only half-hold. The night pressed in with a quiet weight, the way a church door does when it’s about to close on you mid-step. The streetlight above flickered in a way that wore at the nerves—one slow pulse, then another, as if the lamp were blinking at us with mischief or malice, I couldn’t tell which.

The man—if that’s what he was—stood with the suspicious stillness of a mannequin that had learned to breathe. He wore a suit that was almost respectable, all neat lines and pressed pockets, but the fabric seemed to cling and shift in ways fabric should not. His hands rested by his sides, and yet the fingers trembled with a life he did not deserve. His head moved with a precision that felt obscene in a world that never fully obeyed physics. When his gaze found us, it didn’t settle; it siphoned our silhouettes into his own glassy, unblinking reflection.

Sam stepped back a pace, one boot scuffing the pavement as if he expected the earth to swallow us whole and spit us out somewhere safer, somewhere where the air carried a human scent. “Stop,” he repeated, softer now, and the command carried less heat and more request, as though he knew stopping was the only possible mercy we had left.

I tried to speak, but words—oh, how useless words were in that moment. The memory of what I knew, of how I had learned to read the world in the corners of a room, came to me like a tremor under the skin. It wasn’t just that the man looked wrong—though he did, and more than that—but that the air around him felt wrong in a way I could not describe without sounding ridiculous, as if the atmosphere itself had learned to wear a costume and call it polite. The world, suddenly, had a seam along which truth split open and allowed something that should have stayed hidden to peek out just enough to frighten a child again.

Sam’s voice broke through my reverie. “This one doesn’t belong to the crowd.” The certainty in his tone carried a gravity I hadn’t always trusted in him, but tonight I needed to trust it more than I needed my next breath. The man’s eyes flashed in a way that suggested a switchblade gleam behind them, and the mouth beneath his nose barely moved when he spoke—the vowel sounds were clipped, almost machine-made, as if the sound itself had been pressed into a mold and left to harden.

“Do you know what we are?” he asked, the question sliding across the rain-dark street with a smile that wasn’t a smile.

The answer was in the way his jaw did not flex with effort, in the way the teeth did not bite the air as a true human would when forming sound. It was in the too-smooth skin, the absence of pores the way there should be, the way the eyelids did not blink enough to be human. I had seen things like this before—in old houses with stuttering pipes and too-clean walls, in shadows that didn’t quite end where they should. My mind clung to those memories like a drowning man to a rope: a lesson learned in a place where the truth wore a mask of normalcy until you believed so hard you forgot what fear looked like.

Sam stepped closer to the man, closer than prudence allowed, and spoke with a breath of steel in his voice. “We’re leaving.” It wasn’t a question; it was a dare, a blade aimed at whatever game this thing was playing with us. The man’s head tilted, and the movement was wrong in the way a clock tilts when it has forgotten its own hands. He followed us with that unsettling stillness, the kind that makes you feel watched by something that is not alive enough to be called a observer but alive enough to be dangerous.

The street changed with us, or perhaps we changed with it. A storefront’s window, once hopeful with the glow of cheap coffee and a poster of a dancing drummer, now reflected us back in a way that did not look like us at all. My reflection wore a widening mischief of eyes—eyes that belonged to the world of the dream you forget as soon as you wake, but the memory never quite leaves you. The thing, too, was reflected, but not by a mirror: it was reflected by the window’s glass, the kind of glass that multiplies and distorts if you look at it wrong. I felt the prick of a thousand tiny questions against the skin of my mind, the sort that arrive when you stand on a threshold you cannot see.

Sam caught my sleeve and tugged me toward a narrow alley, a path between two brick faces that smelled of rain and old paint, a corridor of damp and noise that existed in the margins of the city’s heartbeat. The alley narrowed, and with it the world did something else: the hum of the city shrank, and the air grew colder, heavier, more private. The man followed, but his steps faltered as if the alley had a temperament he did not anticipate.

“What are you?” Sam demanded again, voice a thread of wire, as if fear could be hammered flat by the strength of certainty.

The entity did not answer in words. Instead, its gaze slid toward a doorway at the end of the alley—a door with a sign that flickered in a way that suggested it did not want to be read by human eyes. The door was old, its paint peeling, its knocker cold as a stone. It looked ordinary until you realized it did not belong to the world you knew, as if it existed because it should not, a gate that did not exist in a map but existed in memory.

“Through there,” I whispered, the word tasting like metal on my tongue. It wasn’t a suggestion to escape so much as a recognition of a path the universe offered when you had the nerve to take it. The entity’s head turned again in that unnatural click of a neck, and its shoulders shifted, as if it were a marionette and someone else was pulling strings. It stood in a posture that looked almost human, but the frame was wrong, the space inside the ribs too neat, as if the heart ran on a battery rather than blood.

Sam muttered something about a bus station and a late-night ride to the edge of the city where the stench of salt and seaweed would confuse any curious onlooker. It wasn’t a plan so much as a last resort: move, avoid, survive. The world narrowed to the doorway, to the dust motes dancing in a stray beam of light, to the sound of rain tapping out a rhythm that felt like a countdown.

We stepped into the doorway, and the air shifted, a mix of damp and something metallic, a perfume that whispered of other places. The room beyond was not a room so much as a moment suspended in carelessness: a corridor filled with doors that led to rooms that did not belong to any building we knew, doors that hummed at a different frequency than the world outside. The entity paused on the threshold, as if a line had been drawn through its heart and it needed permission to cross.

Sam’s breath fogged in the air, and he turned to me with the gentle, stubborn look that told me he would not let fear speak for us. “We need to choose,” he said, and the decision sounded like a vow.

The truth of what we faced pressed in at that moment, not as a scream from the outside but as a creeping certainty from within: these things did not merely imitate us to observe. They inhabited the world between, took the shape of ordinary life so well you forgot to look for the seams. They were not random intruders; they were keepers of a threshold, curators of who could remain and who would vanish into the ordinary blur of a city’s night.

I do not know what gave me the final push, perhaps the memory of a grandmother’s warning whispered in dust along a shelf, or perhaps the simple, brutal desire to keep my brother safe. We chose the door that did not feel as if it belonged to a real place but belonged to a memory we had never lived. The door opened onto a hallway that smelled of rain and something sweet—almost pleasant, a trap of scent designed to soothe the wary mind into a false sense of security.

On the other side, we found not safety but something closer to truth: a room with a single chair and a mirror on the wall. The mirror was odd, not because it showed us unchanged but because it refused to show us completely. It offered a glimpse of our own reflections, but not the full image; the edges of our faces drifted as if someone had painted us against the glass with a brush that wore out halfway. The entity stood just behind us, a silhouette at the very edge of the mirror’s field, and as if the mirror’s law of reflection bent to its will, the silhouette seemed to lean closer to us than any real creature could.

“Why do you imitate us?” Sam asked, voice still steel but now edged with something like sadness. The question did not require a reply; the room answered with a soft, almost affectionate chime—the door we had entered through sighed closed of its own accord, and the corridor beyond grew darker, like night has become a curtain drawn tight around a stage.

The entity stepped into the glow of a single bulb, and for the first time I saw what lay beneath the human skin it wore: a geometry of joints and lines, a labored breathing that didn’t match the rise and fall of a chest, a pulse that sounded in my ears as if it himself carried a second heartbeat, something large and distant and cold. It spoke not with words but with a pressure in the air, like the moment a storm decides to descend.

“We are here because you know,” it said, or whatever it does when it speaks without voice. The words did not spill from its mouth; they pressed on our skin, a gravity that you could feel rather than hear. I could tell Sam heard it too, his jaw clenched as if he were biting down on a scream.

We did not stay to listen to the rest. We pivoted, breaking the spell of the room, and ran, fleeing down the corridor that blurred and warped as if space itself were tired of us. We did not look back, and in the moment of fear I realized the truth I had not admitted to myself: we would never be safe as long as the world hummed with these thresholds, as long as there were corners where a human could slip away and a shape could slip in.

Outside, the rain had stopped, leaving the street a slick, silent mirror. The city began to breathe again, a little slower now, and for a breath I believed we might be invisible. But invisibility, I learned, is an illusion when you have learned to notice the seams—the tiny irregularities in the air, the way a shadow stretches a fraction too long, the way a person’s smile never quite reaches their eyes.

Sam looked at me then, the grass of the curb sticking to his shoes as he stood at the edge of the sidewalk. “We know now,” he said, not triumphantly but with the quiet certainty of someone who has faced the impossible and still chosen to walk forward. “We know what to do next time.”

And I understood that next time would come, that the world would always keep these doorways open somewhere, waiting to test the truth you hold onto in the night. I did not know what the exact answer would be when the next door appeared, or what it would demand of us. But I did know this: I would trust Sam’s certainty, even when it led us into a shadowed street or toward a door that did not belong to the city—or perhaps belonged to a city we were never meant to enter at all.

I cannot tell you how I knew what I knew. I just knew. And now I have a story to tell, a story about a night when a brother’s warning and a line of danger carved itself into the bones of two siblings, about a truth that hides in plain sight behind a smile and a suit and a person who should have been ordinary. If you listen closely, you can hear the rain in the distance again, the faint hum of a door’s hinge waiting to decide what happens to the next person who walks past. And perhaps, if you listen long enough, you’ll hear a whisper that sounds very much like my own voice, asking you to stop, to look, to remember that not everything that wears a human form is one of us.

samples.prompt: You die. The words 'Game Over' appear in front of you, along with 'Thanks for Playing!' Scientists then excitedly remove a headset and various wires from you and ask for constructive feedback.
samples.output:
The moment I die, the words appear as if someone pressed a neon-stencil into the air right in front of my eyes: Game Over. They hover there, perfectly unambiguous, a bright red warranty for the inevitable. Beneath them, in a smaller, friendlier font, Thanks for Playing! It isn’t cruel, really. It’s almost courteous, as if the game apologizes for how it just ended for me and then invites me to applaud the designers for a well-told session.

Then the world—the nothing that was there just a heartbeat ago—clicks into something else. A cold, clinical brightness floods my senses, a smell I’d recognize anywhere: copper, antiseptic, something disinfected but alive. I’m aware of being still; that is, I’m still somewhere in a body, but that body feels wrong now, as if someone swapped the stops on a piano and left the keys vibrating in unfamiliar tunes.

The room is a white hospital of thinking: spotless walls, a ceiling that looks like it could be a solar panel, a soft hum in the air. There’s a bed, beige sheets tucked around a figure with a shaved head, wires trailing like rebellious vines from a neuro-headset that sits on the skull and clamps gently at temples. A pair of scientists stand at the foot of the bed, two men in white coats with the sheen of something still wet, like freshly minted coins. Their faces are pale with the precision of people who see the world in data. Their eyes are the kind that don’t miss anything—every microexpression reads as if their minds were open books.

“Welcome back,” says one, and the words feel like they’re meant for more than just a guest who checked out early. He tilts his head, a question hidden behind a practiced smile. “Not back, really. But you’re still here with us. We’ve got you detached now. Headset off, wires removed. We’ve got what we needed.”

The other raises the box of gadgets they’ve just stripped from me—headset, the mind-oil of cables, little connectors that looked innocent enough but carried the weight of a thousand decisions—and sets them on a chrome trolley. Their actions are careful, almost reverent, as if handling relics from another civilization. They step back, and the sterile room seems to hold its breath with me.

“Constructive feedback,” one of them says, as if he’s presenting a TED Talk and I’m the final, crucial slide. “If you’ve got thoughts about the experience, we’d love to hear them. What worked? What didn’t? What could we do better?”

I blink, which is to say I try to blink, and the image of my own eyelids feels detached from the memory of blinking. I went from living to dying to being a subject in a glass case of a laboratory where the currency is experience and the product is a more perfectly tuned life. The word feedback makes the room tilt, almost in a way that’s more unsettling than the actual darkness I’ve just observed in the moments before the headset came apart from my skull.

I clear my throat, or at least I attempt to. The voice that answers isn’t loud, but it’s mine enough to feel natural: calm, a little practiced, the kind of voice you use when you want to appear brave in front of a jury of scientists.

“First,” I say, “thank you for the ... well, for the opportunity. For the experiment.” I pause, and the sentence feels like it deserves to be finished with something more honest than polite, but the honesty hasn’t come yet; it’s sitting in the wings, patient, still adjusting to the brighter lights and the absence of the headset’s halo around my perception. “If you’re asking what worked,” I continue, “I think your design got the emotional arc right—life is a sequence of choices, and choices have consequences that feel meaningful in the moment but sometimes slip away when you replay them in a test environment.”

The scientist nods, as if my sentence was a protocol he had laminated and filed away. “Go on,” he says.

“The immersion was convincing,” I say, deciding not to sugarcoat it. “I believed in the world you gave me—whether it was a hospital corridor or a city street, it felt real enough to care. The problem wasn’t the craft; it was the underlying premise. If this is your ‘afterlife beta,’ then the ethics need to be revised.”

The other scientist sighs, a sound that mixes disappointment with a spark of anticipation. “Explain.”

“Reality,” I say, thinking about my own dying body, about the way I’d held my breath too long during a moment of fear or longing, “feels heavier when you know you’re being observed. Not watched like a zoo animal, not judged by the gods, but measured—by you. By the people who built the world and now want to learn from the way it crumples or glows when a life ends. The problem isn’t the headset; it’s the expectation that the end is the end. If you’re testing the ‘meaning of a life,’ then you have to let the meaning matter beyond your notes.”

The first scientist frowns a fraction, then looks as if a new thought just arrived at his desk: “You’re saying we should let it matter to the audience?” He gestures toward the room, toward the blank, shining walls.

“Not the audience,” I reply, choosing my words with care. “The subject—the one who lived it. The person who felt the fear, the laughter, the tiny, ridiculous triumphs—the moments of ordinary stubbornness that aren’t dramatic enough to write in a report but are what a life is built of. If you remove the possibility of moral consequence, you remove the purpose of telling a life story at all.”

They exchange a quick glance that passes for a silent agreement, a handshake without hands. Then they stop, and I realize the truth: I am still stuck inside the game’s end screen, a player who died mid-quest who’s now being asked how to design the next level. They want to refine their engine, their “afterlife simulator,” not because they care about me as a person, but because they’re hungry for a better product.

“Thank you,” the other scientist says, almost as if I’ve offered them a license to improve their own souls. “That’s concrete. We can work with that.” He jots something on a clipboard that seems to be a patient chart, except the words aren’t about vital signs; they’re about narrative fidelity and ethical safeguards. The room grows a touch warmer, or perhaps I do.

I realize the strange, almost miraculous thing: I’m not done. I’ve died, yes, but the game isn’t over for the designers, and perhaps not even for me. The sun will still rise somewhere in this experiment, and I can still leave a note, a line of code in a living machine’s memory.

“Two more thoughts,” I say. The words feel heavier than the ones that came before, because I sense I’m about to risk something like vulnerability with a capital V. “First: give the subject a choice. Don’t script the end. Give me the sense that I can pause, reflect, even resist the instruction to ‘play the next loop’ if I want to see what happens when I do nothing. Second: let memory be a thread that survives beyond the current session. If you pull it out entirely, the life starts to feel like a story that ends in a footnote, rather than a full circle.”

The room remains quiet for a heartbeat that seems to stretch into an eternity, then the head scientist speaks again, softly, almost as if he’s whispering to a frightened child who’s just discovered a shadow. “We can discuss these. We need to. This isn’t about punishment—it’s about potential. If your life is a game, we want to be better at designing it so it feels honest.”

He places a gloved hand on the chrome trolley, as if steadying the relics of the experiment that would soon be tucked away again. “Would you mind if we kept your feedback anonymous? We’ll present this as part of a larger dataset. No personal prints, just the design notes.”

The idea of anonymity feels like a mercy. It is both non-binding and oddly intimate: the sense that my thoughts could help someone else walk through the same gate I did, and maybe on a future day avoid the same missteps I perceive now.

“Not at all,” I tell him, and the words arrive like a soft wind that refuses to take sides in the argument of who deserves credit for any truth spoken aloud. “Just tell the truth about what felt wrong and what felt true. Don’t pretend the end was a neat, wrapping ribbon. If you want to tell a life story, tell the messy parts too—the fights, the stubborn love, the small, unremarkable acts of care that kept someone going long enough to matter to others.”

They nod, scribble again, the sounds of pens scratching through paper as if revealing a map of a world bigger than their lab, bigger than me.

And then, the door opens, and a warmth brushes my skin—the first real warmth I’ve felt in what seems like a measured eternity. A voice, not male or female, just a tone of quiet recognition, says, “We’ll begin again. We’ll rebuild this level with all your notes in mind.”

I watch as the two scientists turn away, their bodies adapting to the next set of experiments—another run, another life to pilot through a landscape of choices. The headset is not just removed; it’s set on a table with reverence, as if it had housed a small universe inside its circuits and needed a moment of peace before its next use.

Before the door closes, I speak again, not to plead but to offer a final piece of immortality in this new world: a belief in the possibility that a life, once lived, can teach a creator to craft something kinder. If there is a “level up” to be earned here, it’s not the conquest of fear or the accumulation of points, but the willingness to listen—to listen to the life you’ve already recorded and to the echo of the person who’s asking for a fair chance to finish a thought, to complete a sentence, to decide again what it means to live.

As the door slides shut, the neon letters drift back into view, faint but persistent: Game Over. Thanks for Playing. But this time, I hear a new, softer postscript spoken by the room itself, a line the designers cannot erase: This was not the end of you; it was the beginning of us listening. The end of one loop and the tentative birth of another. And perhaps, in this strange afterlife of design, a chance to write a better ending for someone else someday.

samples.prompt: You were pleasantly surprised that the dragon was actually rather delighted to see your party enter their cave. Turns out that dragons have phases in regards to what they hoard and this dragon was keen on letting you take what you want to clear up space for their new obsession.
samples.output:
You push aside the heavy moss-draped rock that serves as a cave entrance and step into a warm, candlelit chamber that glitters with a different kind of treasure than you expected. The dragon sits curled atop a mound that could choke a mountain in gold and gems, but tonight its gaze isn’t fixed on the hoard. It’s fixed on you, and there’s a certain spark of delight in its eyes that makes you do a double-take: dragons are supposed to be dangerous, or at least greedy, not pleased to see a party of adventurers.

“Ah, visitors,” the dragon says, and its voice is a warm wind threaded with smoke and curiosity. “How punctual you are. Come closer; I am in a good mood to see new faces wander into my humble cave.” Its tone is almost domestic, as if the hoard were merely a garden and the cave an oversized parlor where guests drop by to borrow a moment of gossip.

The room hums with memory and meaning. The air carries a faint tang of copper and sea salt from coins that once slept under tides of dust, the scent of amber and rain from artifacts that have known many hands, and a soft, musky perfume that speaks of patience. For a moment you forget that you came here to stray with danger and win wealth. Here, in the glow of the dragon’s hospitality, you sense something else entirely: a creature who has learned to love change.

The dragon tilts its head and studies you with a keen, almost affectionate gaze. “Dragons have phases, you know,” it says, as if sharing a secret with a friend across a smoke-wreathed table. “We do not hoard the same thing forever, not even us. Phases are ways to keep the world honest about what it means to want something anew.” It rises a little, shifting the mound of gold with a careful motion that suggests this is a living thing, not a fortune pinned to a rock.

“Tonight,” the dragon continues, “I am in a phase you might call the Chisel Phase—though that’s prosaic. Think instead of what a dragon’s hoard becomes when the heart wants to re-sculpt its own obsession. A phase is a lens, a tool, a way to practice letting go so that something else can fill the space you’ve cleared.”

You glance around at the hoard with new eyes. It’s startling to imagine a dragon voluntarily shifting its fixation, letting go of the glimmering cache that has defined many a tale. The dragon senses your curiosity and smiles, a crescent of teeth that glints like polished ivory. “You’ve entered my cave in the midst of transition,” it says. “If you’ve come to take what you can carry, you’ll find me inclined to spare you the heavier burdens. Today I wish to clear space for something I am about to obsess over anew.”

A soft, almost conspiratorial chuckle rumbles from deep inside the dragon’s chest. It lowers its head to your level and indicates the back wall with a sweeping claw—an arched expanse that isn’t as densely packed with gold as the rest of the cave. There, scattered in a more deliberate arrangement, you notice a collection that seems almost purposeful in its emptiness: a band of shelves with a few carefully selected items laid out like instruments in a chamber orchestra.

“This is the current motif of my fascination,” the dragon explains, and you realize what it is even before it says the word. It’s not gold, not gems, not relics of empire. It’s sound and memory encoded in objects. There are instruments—an old brass horn that has learned to sing with the rain, a lute whose strings glow faintly in the dark, a drum carved from a storm-wrapped drumhead that holds the echo of thunder in its hollow. There are vessels that carry sound in liquid form, pendants that hum when touched, bells that ring with the color of a sunset. And there are oddities that are less instrument than memory keepers—a bottle that tastes of a winter morning when you were six, a map that rearranges itself to reveal a chorus of voices from places you’ve never known.

“The new obsession is not merely sound,” the dragon continues, as if reading your thoughts. “It is the collection of echoes. The archive of what an act sounds like when it is done with true intention. If I can bottle a sound’s story—its memory, its longing—I can channel it into something that creates as well as consumes.” The dragon’s eyes brighten with the fever of an idea forming. “And I want space to pursue it. Space to hear the future calling.”

You feel a prickle of something like awe. Dragons often speak grandly of power and dominion, yet here is one confessing a desire to cultivate, to curate, to listen. It’s disarming in a way that makes you trust the odds of this encounter a little more than the odds of a typical ambush.

“So,” the dragon says, almost casually, “you came here seeking something to claim or barter. I am offering you a simple agreement: take what you need, so long as you leave behind enough to let me follow this new fixation.” It gestures around the chamber with a sweep of its tail, as if to say, choose with purpose, for time is part of the treasure now.

The offer lands with surprising ease. The dragon’s phase is, in a sense, a generous reset: it invites the adventurers to choose items that will help them on their quest while also enabling the dragon to pursue something delicate and experimental. The party exchanges quick glances, each member weighing the value of memory against the lure of new adventures ahead.

You step forward and begin to examine the curated section at the back of the cave. The brass horn, whose notes cycle through a gentle brass-tinged melody when you touch it, could be a priceless ally for a party that thrives on morale and direction. The storm-drum, if struck with the right rhythm of courage, might quell a raging scene or open a door that yields a whisper of a path. The map that rearranges itself to reveal voices: a tool for negotiation with strangers who speak through memory rather than mouth.

There are also more idiosyncratic items—glimmering pendants whose hum shifts with the wearer’s heartbeat, a bottle of winter morning that could freeze time for a heartbeat or two, a painting that shifts its colors with the weather outside, telling you when a trap lies ahead by the shade of its sky. Each item feels like a doorway to another story, a potential ally in a story you are living and a thread you could pull to unravel another.

The dragon watches as you deliberate, its tail curled around a coin-pile like a cat around a sunbeam. “Take what you need for your journeys,” it says, “and I will take what I need for mine—space for the stage on which my new obsession will perform.” It pauses, almost smiling at the idea of a dragon composing its own symphony of sound—and then adds, almost shyly, “If you want to know where the future drifts, leave behind something of your own that speaks to your own next chapter. The future likes a good echo from the past.”

A hush settles over the chamber as the party weighs the moral weight of what they take. In a strange way, the dragon’s generosity is a test of trust, not trickery. It’s not about who can take the most but who can decide wisely what helps the next leg of their journey while allowing a creature they’ve just met to cultivate a new passion.

You finally settle on a small bundle: the brass horn, a shard of the storm-drum’s edge that can be used as a shield against fear, and a pendant that hums in the palm like a heartbeat you recognize from home. You leave behind a few ordinary trinkets—their value in the moment diminished when compared to the living, breathing possibility of the dragon’s new obsession. The dragon nods, approving your choices not only for their usefulness but for their quiet respect of its personal transformation.

As you prepare to depart, the dragon lowers its head to your level once more. “Remember this window,” it says, “the chance to exchange what you were with what you will become. I have no quarrel with your mission; I merely ask that you listen for the note you did not know you were missing, and that you carry it with you from now on.”

The moment you turn to go, the cave seems to come alive with a new resonance. A gentle chorus of materials—horns and drums and pendants—begins to sing in their own soft voices, as if the dragon’s new obsession is already shaping the cave into a living instrument. You feel the air vibrate with possibility, as if every echo carries a rumor of distant doors swinging open.

Outside, the world carries its ordinary weight: footprints on dirt, distant calls of other travelers, the scent of rain still on the horizon. Yet your pack holds something a little lighter and a lot more curious than before: an instrument tuned to a future you can almost hear, a memory you have chosen to carry forward, and a promise that, if you ever return, the cave will be ready to lend you its chorus again.

You step back into the daylight with that strange, buoyant feeling that you’ve not merely survived a dragon’s lair but have witnessed a creature choosing to grow in a way you can admire. The dragon watches you go with a nod and a soft, almost personal smile, as if to say, until next time, when the sound of your story returns to me in a new key. And as you walk away, the cave—bright with the first tentative echoes of a new obsession—seems to exhale, grateful for the space and the company.

samples.prompt: After years of study, you have finally made contact with the eldritch spirit. However, it needs a body to inhabit. Last night's blizzard has driven most creatures into hiding, and you won't offer yourself. Desperately looking out your window, your neighbor's snowman suddenly catches your eye.
samples.output:
After years of study, I finally coaxed a voice from the black sea of equations and patient practice, a voice that did not merely echo through chalk dust but answered back. The thing on the other end is eldritch in the old sense: without form, too large to fit into the frame of my skull, and yet it remembers how a body is supposed to feel, as if it once wore skin too heavy to notice. It needs a body to inhabit, a mouth to speak through, lungs to hold the wind in their cages and release it with a sigh that can sound like a threat or a lullaby, depending on its mood.

For years I assumed I would be the host of last resort, the person who offered their own chest as a corridor for something that would write new geometry on the inside of me. The thought tormented me in sleepless nights and appeared again in the daylight, in the corners of the room where the light pooled and pretended to be normal. Then last night, a blizzard far beyond ordinary winter demands attention—white and roaring and merciless—drags every creature into hiding. The street becomes a pale animal with its ears folded back, listening for something it cannot name. And I, stubbornly, refuse.

I stand at the window, watching the world shrink behind the turning glass. The wind hurls snow sideways as if it wants to wipe the town off the map, and the world beyond the glass asks me to decide what it means to be alive in a place where life is hard to define. The trees lean against the grey sky, their limbs like old, patient fingers coaxing prayers from the air. The storm has a way of muting sound, the center of gravity of things shifting imperceptibly, so that even your heartbeat seems to slow to match the drift of snow.

And then, an ordinary thing—a thing I have seen a hundred times without noticing its possible altitudes of meaning—becomes a locality of danger and possibility. The neighbor’s snowman stands in the yard under the streetlamp’s pale halo, a silent witness to winter’s etiquette. It wears the scarf my neighbor bought at the end of last season, the scarf that never quite fits the voice of his house, the scarf that smells faintly of pine and the wool’s long, patient memory of warmth. The coal eyes are not mine, not any child’s cheek-pink memory of happiness, but a stubborn gleam that seems to watch a world it never walked in. It is a very ordinary snowman, an object one would pass without a second glance, unless it is required to perform a function beyond its nature.

Yet there is a demand in the air—no, a whisper—the same whisper the eldritch thing uses to remind me of promises whispered in the dark when the world was younger and gentler and more cruel. It reminds me that a body is not merely a sack for a soul but a map, a lock, a foothold in a place where gravity has defined weaknesses. It asks me to consider what I would give to a place that does not breathe. I did not realize until this moment that I am the one who has learned to hear its voice with the proper concentration, the pulse that stitches physics with longing.

The blizzard seems to have carved out a window of opportunity. It has driven every creature indoors, either to hide or to nurse old wounds. It has left my options sparse but not non-existent. The snowman in the neighbor’s yard remains a sentinel, an inert monument to winter’s stubbornness. Its presence suddenly feels like a trap that the universe laid out for me and me alone to walk into.

The proposition—or perhaps the only route to survival for the eldritch thing—appears not as a grand, heroic gesture but as a deliberately small, almost delicate act: inhabit a body that is already there, in the sense that it is a thing that exists in the world with a memory of being alive. The snowman exists precisely as something that was never alive, and for that reason it might be the perfect vessel. It requires no consent, no sigh of relief from a nervous, living thing, no ambiguity about a body’s boundaries. The snowman is a shape, a closed case, a container that can be opened only by someone who knows the world’s edges and how to slip through them.

I approach the window again, my breath fogging the glass with a rapid, anxious fog that mirrors my thoughts. The snowman’s coal eyes seem to flicker when a gust bites through the yard and lifts some of the loose flakes around its base, as if the winter had just blinked and decided to re-inspect its own creation. The thought comes to me with a chill that is not entirely fear: what if the snowman’s cold, blank exterior might serve as a better boundary for something which, if given a body, should not be allowed to wander? The one thing the world seems to have kept sacred is thickness of skin and the stubbornness of interior laws about what counts as life. A snowman, though, is not a violation of those laws—it is proof that the laws can be bent, heated, reshaped, and made to yield a little of their own contradiction.

The ritual is simpler than I expected, and I tell the eldritch so with the sound of the wind in the eaves, which I pretend to be only the storm’s skeptical whisper. It asks me to slow my pulse, to exhale softly, to pretend for a moment that I am not a laboratory instrument but a harbor. It asks me to imagine the snowman as a hollow shell: the head, the torso, and arms that end in nothing but the air’s memory of wood and sinew. It asks me to imagine filling that shell with something older than breath—something that remembers the slow turning of planets and the quiet terror of knowing all the angles we think we know are only constellations invented to make sense of the dark.

If I give the snowman a body, it will not become mine. It will become a new address for the eldritch thing, a place where it can speak without the friction of human lips, a vessel to hold its language and project it outward, to leak through the snow’s crystalline skin into the world. It will speak in the language of pressure changes in winter air, of frost that clings to the bones of a house, of a memory of something vast moving behind the surface of things. It will be subtle, insidious, and absolute.

The moment arrives when I stand at the window and let the wind touch the back of my neck as if it were a hand trying to coax me into confidence. I do not physically touch the snowman; I do not lay my hand on it in any intimate sense. Instead, I do something simpler and more terrible in its precision: I open a channel, a window not in glass but in the mind, through which the world’s raw cold can pass and the eldritch’s voice can become audible to something other than a reed-thin human ear. I invite it to inhabit the snowman, not my chest.

The process is not dramatic. There is no burst of heat, no tearing of flesh, no eruption of color. It is a slow, patient seeping of the being into the beingless thing. The snowman becomes faintly animated, a tremor of presence in the form that once only existed as snow. Its arms, once hollow and still, begin to stretch in that way winter things sometimes do when the world’s weight shifts and the season persuades the air to pretend it’s alive. The coal eyes glow—not with life, but with a kind of pale curiosity that belongs to something older than sight.

From the glass I watch the new body assume the shape and discipline of the old winter sentinel. The snowman takes on a subtle, almost ridiculous dignity, as if it had always carried a crown of frost beneath its scarf. The eldritch thing speaks now, a private recommencement of a language older than the town and older than the storm; it speaks through the form of the snowman, and the words come out as a cold wind that carries the stinging bite of ice and the sorrowful whisper of distant stars.

To my relief, I do not lose myself in its presence. The mind that speaks through the snowman is not mine; it is a broader, colder thinking that does not need the warmth of a diaphragm to breathe. I feel what the storm’s power can do, the way it can bend the architecture of a city’s nerves to whisper a new rule: bodies are not sacred; they are instruments, and the world is full of spare parts. The snowman—the neighbor’s snowman—becomes a vessel that is both alien and intimate, a paradox I can tolerate only because the alternative is a continent of silence.

The world outside does not change immediately. No sirens, no lights, no sudden blooming of strange life from the whitened ground. It is only the quiet of a house at the edge of a snow-laden street, and a man at a window who has learned too much, who possesses the means to bend the universe just enough to prevent the other from swallowing him whole. The neighbor’s yard remains a small stage on which the winter drama plays out—a blackbird’s silhouette on a white field, a snowman that now breathes faintly through the frost, a new mouth for the thing I summoned but did not wish to be.

And yet I am not free of responsibility. I have given the snowman a body, but not a life anchored in the ordinary order of things. The eldritch is patient; it wants to learn how a body moves, how to translate intent into action through a perfect, glassy surface of winter. It will require time—the reason I avoided offering my own flesh in the first place, the reason I chose a form that cannot bleed or tire or mutiny with the heat of blood.

So I stand at the window and watch the world reduce itself to a simple geometry: a house, a yard, a snowman with coal eyes and a scarf, a cold wind that could be a whisper of something older than the snow. The storm continues to howl in a way that suggests it has learned to be more precise, more patient, more dangerous than before. The snowman’s mouth is a mere suggestion, a line drawn with frost that I have learned to trust as a sign of assent. The elder has begun to speak its own name in the blue-tinted language of ice.

What happens next is not a spectacle but a quiet, creeping rearrangement of the town’s memory. The snowman will remain in the neighbor’s yard, a vessel with a living breath but no heartbeat of its own. The blizzard’s memory will cling to the edges of doors and windows, to the warmth left by radiators, to the cold that keeps hidden the things that do not wish to be seen. The eldritch voice will settle into the snow’s grain, and the body it inhabits will become a new kind of thing—one that does not forget the price paid to stand in the world, one that can endure the long, pale hours of winter and still be here when spring forgets to show.

I do not pretend to know what this will become. The world will not declare itself cured or damned by the act of giving a body to a non-being. It will simply endure, as it always does, and let the cold rewrite what it means to be alive, one careful breath at a time. If the snowman can hold both its innocence and the thing that speaks through it, perhaps that is enough to keep us all from dissolving into a further, more intimate darkness.

In the end, the choice was not a heroic leap but a decision to edge away from the self I feared and toward a body that would not demand I surrender my own. If there is a price, I will bear it in a place where winter’s memory is a shield and a warning. The snowman’s eyes are now bright in the lamplight, a pale mirror to the stars above, and the world outside continues to howl and listen, as if it already knows that winter is not a season so much as a doorway—one through which a word can become a thing, and a thing can become a house.

samples.prompt: It’s bad enough that today was the day the rest of your species disappeared, leaving you the only remaining human on Earth. But now, as you gaze out into the vast, empty cosmos above you, you see a collection of lights and realize you were never alone.
samples.output:
It’s bad enough that today was the day the rest of your species disappeared, leaving you the only remaining human on Earth. The world around you wears the quiet like a heavy coat—hastily shrugged on in fear, then left to settle into warmth you no longer need. The city you once haunted lies in a pale, patient ruin: glass windows corroded to a film of rust, streets blooming with weeds and the soft, patient march of time. If any part of you still believed in the possibility of rescue, it is long gone now, burned away by the wind and the distant thunder of a collapsed civilization. I have learned to measure time by the way the light shifts on the far side of the horizon, by the way the dust settles and refuses to move when I curl my fingers around a railing that has grown too hot to touch.
