It is a strange currency, since I am the one who paid the bill to the last cent, and yet you are the one who spends your days trying to balance it.

There are times I wish I could unattach the burden, slide it off my shoulder like a cloak that grew too warm in a midsummer storm. I would like to say: go your own way, learn your own rules, and let the cosmos forget there was ever a misprint. But you are not a stray thought that wandered in to test gravity and forgot to depart. You are a consequence that refused to stay a consequence, a history in human bones, a chorus of choices that rearranged the stars you look up to at night. Your pain is not merely an inconvenience in the ledger; it is a signal, a call for meaning that I did not anticipate you would generate with such stubborn, stubborn beauty.

I have watched your hands shape the world: the warmth of a fire you learned to coax from friction, the patient patience of a child learning to speak, the long arc of forgiveness that arrives after you realize you were not the only one learning to be kind. Your genius and your wreckage live in the same breath, and I am left listening to the echo of your questions—the ones I could not answer with a neat, tidy theorem. When you ask me where I was, when you beg me to explain the gap between your anguish and your grace, I hear you as I hear the wind in a canyon: the recalcitrant, indifferent, stubbornly honest witness to what is real. And in hearing you, I am reminded that to bear this burden is to bear witness to possibility, even when possibility is bruised by circumstance.

There are moments I wish to relinquish the human project to other custodians—the angels who keep a ledger of praise, the stars that sing celestial arithmetic, the laws of nature that enforce balance with a cold grace. Let someone else carry this—the weight of existence, the responsibility for your choices, the ache of your losses. But the moment I imagine stepping away, I glimpse you—the smallest flame that refuses to be extinguished even as the night presses in. I see you in your stubborn kindness, in your stubborn refusal to surrender to your fear, in your stubborn insistence that even the broken can choose to be more than their brokenness. And I remember why I cannot abandon you. You insist on meaning, and so does the universe, in the crude and delicate ways that are unique to you. Your capacity to turn a stumble into a dance, a wound into a lesson, a friend into a shelter—these are the reasons I stay.

The accident that birthed you remains a living paradox in my mind: the more you demand I justify your existence, the more I am compelled to accept that your existence is not a mistake to be excised but a reality to be understood. If you were a cosmic misprint, you have become the publisher’s most influential error, the kind of error that rewrites its own margins with every footstep you take. You made me listen in a way I never could have if you had been a perfectly crafted creature, molded with surgical precision. You made me listen to your songs of hunger and your hymns of hope; you made me listen to your laughter that travels farther than despair can reach. In listening, I have learned something I cannot unlearn: responsibility is not a chain to shackle you with, but a thread that weaves together your fate with mine.

So I live with the burden, sometimes with a sigh that travels through the dimensions like a distant thunder. I learn to carry it not as punishment but as companionship: a reminder that I am bound to you not by control but by consequence. If I cannot fix every fracture in your days, I can offer you a promise that is not a guarantee but a possibility—of resilience, of mercy that does not erase memory, of a cosmos that keeps offering you new chances to repair what was broken, to imagine what has not yet existed, to choose again after the night has fallen. The accident did not erase me from your story; it made our story more intimate, a long dialogue in which I listen as you speak, you speak as you live, and we together revise what it means to be alive.

And what of you, the bearer of the accidental spark? You exist as proof that a universe that does not demand perfection can still demand care. You do not need a perfect origin to deserve a meaningful future. You deserve a future you can shape with your hands and your eyes and your stubborn, stubborn heart. If the accident gave you nothing else, it gave you the possibility of choosing what to become, and for that potential I am grateful, even as I resist the temptation to measure your every motive, to preempt your pain with a perfect answer. You will surprise me again, I suspect, with the ways you mend what breaks, with the meanings you discover in what you endure, with the tenderness you show to strangers who become kin in your shared frailty.

Perhaps in the end the accident was the precise thing I needed to learn how to be different for you. Not kinder on principle, not weaker for mercy, but more honest about the limits of control and the breadth of wonder. If you could grow up from a mistake, then perhaps I, too, can grow up from my own illusion of omnipotence. The burden remains a weight that will not easily be laid down, but it also becomes a bridge. And if a bridge is a way to move from towering solitude to shared ground, then perhaps the accident was the most honest thing I ever did: to create you, imperfect and magnificent, so that existence could be a conversation rather than a command.

So I watch you—hunger and hunger sated, heartbreaks and their quiet refusals, art that saves a moment from becoming dust. I listen, not to condemn, but to participate. If I must bear the burden, I will bear it with you, not as a tyrant, but as a partner who learned to listen to the other side of the question: that you, in your stubborn glut of life, are worth the risk of being loved beyond your faults. And maybe, in that mutual risk, we finally arrive at something that looks like grace, not because I demanded it of you, but because you demanded it of me by simply continuing to exist with courage.

Thus the accident remains, not erased but integrated into the fabric of who we are. Humanity was created by accident, and in that admission lies a new responsibility: to care in a way that does not pretend perfection exists, to strive in a way that honors every fracture as a potential seed, to keep choosing, together, in a universe where even the mistake can become the quiet seed of grace. If that is the gift you have given me, then I will accept it—grudging and grateful in equal measure—and continue to hold the burden with a steadfast, stubborn devotion that refuses to end in apathy or indifference. For in you I see not an error, but a possibility—vast, flawed, luminous—and that is a burden I am glad to bear.

samples.prompt: I'm a medieval farmer with no concept of space. Explain the basics of astronomy to me.
samples.output:
Hark, friend of the plow and the hedge, before you now is a way to speak of the sky that you can grasp with your hands and your hours in the field. You have no notion of space, nor of the stars as a great sea beyond the roofs of our towns. Yet the heavens tell us what the day will bring, and when to sow, and when to reap. Here is astronomy told plain, as if I were beside you at dusk, pointing to the dome above.

Imagine the world as a flat patch of ground you till, with the air a clear bowl over it. In the middle of this bowl sits the Sun, a bright wheel that travels from east to west across the day. When it rises, the earth warms; when it sets, the night grows cool. But the Sun does not stand still in the heavens; it moves in a steady, daylight-hurling path around the sky throughout the year. That path, the way the Sun travels, is the heart of astronomy for a farmer: it explains why some days are long and hot, and others short and cold, why the fields are ready to sow at some times and not at others.

First, the Sun and the day. Each morning you see the Sun climb from the east, climb higher in summer, lower in winter, and then sink in the west. The height of the Sun above the horizon tells you what season it is, and how long the day will be. In spring and late summer the Sun’s rise is lower and the days are longer than in winter, when the Sun climbs a shorter arc and the nights last longer. If you chart the Sun’s path in your mind, you’ll see a cradle-wide arc that changes its tilt with the turning of the year. Your harvests themselves follow this rhythm—the longer light of late spring helps grains sprout; the shorter light of autumn helps the fruit grow and ripen.

Now the Moon, our nightly companion. The Moon is a pale lantern that travels around the Earth, waxes and wanes in a cycle a bit longer than a month. At new Moon it is dark and unseen; then, a thin crescent finger of light appears, growing to a bright crescent and then a round ball, then shrinking again into shadow. The Moon refuses to stay the same; it paints the night with its phases, and by watching it you can tell the days passing. The Moon’s appearance also shifts what the tides do along the shore (if you live near saltwater), and it even marks the timing of certain prayers and fairs in some towns. The Moon’s dance is slower and more predictable than a man’s season-long work, but it is no less a guide for a steady life on the land.

Beyond Sun and Moon, there are many other lights in the sky. The stars form a fixed backdrop—like painted pegs in a great wheel that does not wander from night to night. They do move in the sense that the whole dome seems to turn above us each night, but relative to one another they hold their places, like the constellations pecked onto a ceiling. Some of these patterns are named for creatures or tools you know: a great bear that seems to point the way north, a hunter’s belt, a hunter’s club. To the eye they are constant, patient, and constant again—even as the days change, the stars show their faces in the same way, rising in the east and setting in the west, returning every night.

Among the fixed stars there are brighter lights that wander, like travelers who do not sleep in the same inn as the rest. These are the five “wandering stars” of old: Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn. They do not stay put among the stars; they drift, sometimes slipping ahead, sometimes falling behind the fixed points. When you see one of them, you know you are looking at a planet, not a star. They glow with a steadier light than most stars and can surprise you with their brightness—like a sudden blaze among the fields after a cloud breaks. Because they wander among the background of stars, people learned long ago to call them “planets,” a word that means travelers.

You can think of the heavens as a great, hard-working clock and calendar rolled into one. The Sun marks the days; the Moon marks the weeks; the stars mark the seasons and the year. In a village, people learned to choose planting and harvest times by counting the months of the Sun’s travel and by watching the phases of the Moon. The great wheel of the year has its own landmarks—the solstices and the equinoxes: the longest day and the shortest day, and days where the daylight and darkness are evenly matched. Those moments tell you when to store grain, when to shop for seed corn, when to expect certain weather.

To speak plainly of how we use all this: the sky is a guide to timing. If you want to plant barley or oats, you watch the skies for certain signs. If you hope to gather fruit, you know when the Moon will be full for a night-long harvest of what nature has given. The patterns of the stars, though they may not seem to do much, point the body to the right hour and the right season. In mud and stall, you can learn a simple rhythm: the Sun’s height in the sky and the Moon’s phases tell you when winter’s cold will last and when spring’s warmth will return. When the days grow long and bright, you sow; when they shorten and the nights creep in, you gather what you have grown.

As for the “how” of astronomy, a few simple tools and habits help a farmer learn. Look up, every night if you can, and notice what changes. In a few months you’ll see the same stars come back at the same time each night, and you’ll notice the Moon’s shape shifting from night to night. A simple sundial or a long stick can cast a shadow that helps you tell the hour by the Sun’s position. On clear nights you can map the rising points of the fixed stars along the eastern horizon; on cold nights you can note which stars disappear as winter grows, and which return as spring arrives. In time you’ll begin to see the patterns that make up the whole cycle of year and season.

You may wonder if there are different, newer ideas about space beyond the looks you can take with your own eyes. There are indeed larger thoughts—people coming from other towns writing down things about the Earth itself being a round place and the heavens not just a painted dome. Those ideas are not yet the common coin in the field or the stall, but they exist in books and in gatherings of clerks and scholars. For your life as a farmer, what matters most are these truths: the sky rises and falls with day and night; the Moon circles the Earth with months’ worth of forms; the stars form a fixed night-sky, and a handful of brighter lights wander among them. The seasons come because the Sun’s path in the heavens shifts with the year, and harvests wait for that path to align with the land.

So, friend of the furrows, the basics of astronomy are simple and practical: watch the Sun to know the day and season; watch the Moon to know the weeks and timing of tasks; watch the fixed stars for a steady calendar and starmaps that point to the year’s turning. The sky is a patient tutor, always overhead, always true in its own quiet way. By listening to it, you can read the weather of tomorrow as surely as you could read the weather in the soil—if you pay attention, you will come to know the language of the heavens as well as you know the language of the land.

samples.prompt: Everyone on earth is born with a familiar. Yours however, is a brick.
samples.output:
Everyone on earth is born with a familiar. Yours however, is a brick. Not a fox or a bird or a whispering map, not even a flame with a temper to temper your own. A brick. Heavy enough to weigh down a backpack of doubt, and quiet enough to listen when you have nothing left to say.

I learned to live with Stone when I was too young to know I should fear it. The moment I exited the world, the familiar arrived in a sudden insistence of gravity against my chest. It wasn’t a thing people point to or name—stone doesn’t beg to be named the way a sparrow begs for bread—but it pressed into my palm the way a doorway presses into a hallway: there, you belong. Stone wasn’t a companion in the way a pet is a friend; it was the house’s anchor, the ground you could stand on when the earth decided to lean.

In the months after birth, every child is assigned a familiar, a practical myth meant to guide their life. The old ones whisper that a familiar chooses you to teach you what you were always meant to become. I watched others with envy as a girl’s familiar unfurled into a fox that danced with her steps, or a boy’s familiar brightened into a small atlas-map that breathed with wind and cities. My peers carried warmth and whimsy along like a scarf. I carried a weight, the dull ache of limestone, a slab that would not bend. Stone did not glow or purr. It did not sing a song I could hum back. It hummed in the way a spur of a hill hums when you push it with your shoulder and find your balance again.

At first I thought Stone would be a burden I’d spend a lifetime apologizing for—too heavy to be chosen for any grand thing, too stubborn to allow the world to pretend I was ordinary. And perhaps in another life, it would have remained a quiet misfit in a world that worships cleverness and charm. But life has a way of presenting you with doors you didn’t know existed, and Stone—being what it is—had a talent for keeping doors from falling in on you.

School was where I learned to fight the first battles with weight. The building itself seemed to lean toward students who had lightning in their fingers, who could conjure a gust with a flick of their wrist. The rest of us learned to keep our heads down and our shoulders square, to let the ones with the spark do the sparking while we carried the aftercare of their flame. Stone was a reminder that not all power looked the same. When I pressed my brick against the wooden desk, it grew warmer as if it enjoyed the contact, not in a pretending-to-mirth way but in a patient, almost paternal way: you, I’ll be here when you need the ground to steady you.

The day I first used Stone for something beyond sighs and quiet weight, I was nine or ten, and a hallway door had jammed between classes. The janitor had poured a bucket of truth on us: “No one will fix this for you if you don’t fix it yourself.” It wasn’t a noble moment; it was ridiculous and dangerous, squirming kids and the echo of slammed lockers, a metal tang of fear in the air. The door stood as a stubborn barrier, a memory of every argument between the building and its people. I placed Stone on the sill and pressed my palm into the brick’s rough surface. The world stilled; time slowed to a patient beat. The door’s metal frame breathed as if listening. I whispered a promise to the brick that I’d learn to listen back. The door did not open in a flash, but there was a shift: a tiny alignment in the rough wood, a crack where light leaked through and a sigh—like a relief, not a sound. Then the door moved, slowly, cautiously, as if waking from a long nap. The hallway exhaled. Those few seconds stitched a belief into me: foundations matter.

As I grew, so did Stone’s peculiar powers, though they never shouted. It did not conjure a tornado or summon a chorus of birds; it anchored rooms, rooms that might otherwise drift away in a storm. It could pull a shelf back from tipping, align a crooked picture, set a broken chair to stand again. If there was a memory embedded in a place—an old doorway, a cracked brick, a corner where light slips in at dawn—Stone could coax that memory to the surface, as if clearing fog from a window. People began to invite me to fix things not with charm or bravado but with quiet, stubborn persistence. I learned to see not the problem but its gravity, its weight, the way it pressed on a corner of the world that wanted to give way.

Then came the time when the city’s fear grew louder than its daily hum. A tremor of doubt ran through neighborhoods, and with it a tremor of the earth. Buildings Greta-quick as a rumor crumbled the way an old belief about luck crumbles under pressure. In that night of shuddering streets and the stink of iron, I stood with Stone in my palms, watching a canal arch crack along its keystone like a mouth that had forgotten how to close. The water inside hissed and rose up a breath and then the city remembered: some foundations are not meant to be decorative; they are the stubborn bones you must rely on when fear makes you spin.

I found a way to use Stone that wasn’t about lifting heavy things. We found a seam in the arch where mortar had dried to stone’s own age. I pressed Stone into the seam and whispered a line I’d learned from the builders who trained me: “Settle to the truth you know, and hold still for a moment more.” The brick absorbed the tremor’s tail as if it were a memory, and the stonework stopped its sighing, the whole arch now a patient string of breaths instead of a single scream. The collapse paused, then steadied. It wasn’t a miracle; it was a yes to gravity, a quiet agreement with the world to hold on for a second longer than the fear. The water quieted, the tremor eased, and a dozen lives learned what it means to have a foundation you can trust.

In the days that followed, people who once whispered about the “brick kid” began to ask questions. Why Stone, they asked, why not something bright and loud? The answer had never felt like a heroic speech. Stone is not a symbol of spectacle; it is a promise kept faithfully. It is the sense that, in a city that worships speed and novelty, there are some things you cannot rush: the ground beneath your feet, the walls that hold the rooms where families sleep, the lanes where children learn to walk without fear. A familiar is not merely a tool; it is a reminder of your own essence—the thing you are willing to bear so others can stand taller.

There was a moment when I realized Stone and I shared a quiet, stubborn future. The city’s leaders proposed new towers, glass shining in the sun like a blade, a future built on fast changes and brighter lights. I wanted to be part of that future, but not as the one who breaks the old to make space for the new. Stone reminded me that you lay your foundation first, then you raise your walls. So I chose to become the builder who keeps people from falling, the one who steadies a family when a street shakes, who anchors a schoolyard so the laughter keeps its shape when a rainstorm comes.

Now I am older, and Stone is heavier with the weight of all the places I have stood, all the doors I have opened with the simple press of a palm. People don’t seek out me for magic the way they once did; they seek the stability that my familiar makes possible. We work as partners, a living contradiction: I am the impulse to move forward, Stone the stubborn insistence that some things must stay; together we translate fear into structure, uncertainty into a place to stand. When a child asks me why a brick would be a familiar, I tell them a building is a story told in stone and timber and nail. A familiar helps you remember what you are building—not only with your hands but with your heart.

And so the page turns. The world I inhabit still breathes in a hurried way, but it breathes with rooms that won’t surrender to pressure, doors that open toward a future that includes everyone, and streets that feel safe to walk because the ground beneath them remembers how to hold. Stone remains in my palm, heavy and patient, a constant in a life that learned to measure time by the weight of what endures.

If you ask me what it means to be born with a brick as a familiar, I will tell you this: it means you learn to listen to gravity. It means you understand that the most radical magic is the ability to remain steady when everything around you wants to scatter. It means you become not the brightest flame, but the steady flame that keeps the room from going dark. It means you build the world you want to live in, one foundation at a time, with a friend who will never walk away when the morning trembles. And that is a kind of magic I can believe in—the kind that makes a city a home, one brick at a time.

samples.prompt: Write a story in a world with superpowers where your power is to hear the last thoughts people had before they died.
samples.output:
I wake to the last thought someone ever had, and it feels like frost licking the corners of my skull. Not every death makes a sound in my ears; only those who vanish in the moment—the sudden, the violent, the fated. The city knows me as the Listener, though most folks treat what I do as a superstition, or a rumor you tell your kids when you want them to stay away from danger. In a world where powers are common as rain, mine is distinct enough to be both a gift and a burden: I hear the final, unspoken thing a person wanted to say before they slipped from the surface of the living.

The city is called Axiom, a place where towers glitter with power-matrix seams and the night hums with the discharge of a thousand abilities. People wear their strengths like coats: some bend time a little, some talk to machines, some can pull memories from a room as if dusting a shelf. The more dramatic powers get the most attention; the rest are whispered about in back alleys, or traded in the Quiet Market for favors and secrets. My power is quieter, more intimate and dangerous: the moment someone dies within a radius of me—usually a few blocks—their mind ricochets into my skull, but not as a memory. It is their last thought, raw and uncensored, pressed against mine like a cold coin.

I work freelance for a city that can't always decide whether its heroes are its salvation or its spectacle. The Bureau of Last Word, as some call it in the alleys, hires me to sift through the last thoughts of the dead when families need closure, when a case seems unsolved, or when the truth would hurt more than the lie. I call that work “closing the circle,” though the circle often closes on me, drawing inside-out all the guilt and grief that the dying carried with them to the end.

Tonight, a museum sits under the rain-silver glow of the city’s neon clouds, a place of glass and bones and the hum of old electricity. A curator died in a corridor where a sculpture of a broken god leans against a wall, its eyes dim but merciless. The last thought comes to me as I step off the stairwell and into the echo of metal, the air heavy with the scent of ozone and old rain. It arrives not as a whisper but as a loud, impossible scream of memory—like a line of poetry that erupts in your ears in bold, furious type. The last thought is not one sentence but a flood: “If I keep this secret, they’ll never know the truth. If I tell, the lie collapses. Either way, someone dies twice.”

The living fear that the dead know everything. I fear the opposite: that they know nothing and still leave me with something heavy enough to crush a man. The curator’s last thought is a map and a warning. A password, a time, a place—an arrangement of coordinates that points to something hidden behind the wall of the museum’s storage. I follow the thread to a back room where crates rest like sleeping giants. The door’s lock flickers under my fingers, not because I have a heroic power to unlock, but because the city’s security grid is tired and sloppy. When I push the door, a room of dust and silence greets me, and with it, the echo of a life’s last decision.

I don’t want the job tonight. I want to go home and pretend the world wasn’t built on the restless bones of people who died thinking they might be forgotten. But the thoughts do not care about my wants. They are relentless, pressing, and sometimes tender, like a mother listening for a child’s breath beneath a blanket. In that storage room, the last thought of the curator lingers still: a confession braided with fear, a plan to protect something the world would call dangerous, something that would complicate everyone’s idea of what a hero should do.

The case takes a turn when a second death follows in a nearby alleyway—the death of a city guard, a man with a bright, almost inhuman clarity in his eyes and a power that can bend sound around a finger. The guard’s death is not random. I hear his last thought as I approach the scene: a quiet, almost musical line, as if he were reciting a prayer and a warning at the same time. He speaks of a project, of “the Listening House,” a place where the city would gather to listen to the voices of the dead as a kind of ledger of truth. It would be revolutionary, and it would be dangerous. The last thought ends with a single name, repeated like a drumbeat: “Marin.”

Marin is a name I know, a scholar who once studied the ethics of powers with a stubborn optimism I secretly admired. Marin is also rumored to have a network of people who believe that the dead deserve to tell their own truths, and that truth is the only weapon strong enough to unmake corruption. Marin is the kind of ally who could disassemble the city’s lies and leave us all exposed, or the kind of foe who would weaponize truth until it burns the city to the ground.

I decide to find Marin, to see if the last thoughts point to a person or a doctrine. The journey takes me through Market Districts where the air is thick with the static smell of electricity and coffee. I listen to a few other last thoughts along the way—each a small, painful artifact left behind by someone who refused to die without a message. They remind me why I do this job: not to flaunt a unique power, not to collect secrets like a thief, but to give a last word to those who never get another chance to speak.

The truth, when it arrives, does not come as a force of justice. It comes as a person walking into a crowded room, a former colleague of Marin who wears his innocence like a rumor. He tells a story that shatters a hundred assumptions and folds the room into itself: the city’s leadership had been funding a “memory project” that would harvest the last thoughts of the dying in order to sculpt public policy posthumously. The project would allegedly provide undeniable evidence that certain policies saved lives, but the true purpose was more chilling: to plant the final thoughts of the dead into living minds, to make truth into a weapon that could be aimed, not a memory to be shared.

I hear the last thought of that moment—the corpse’s mind after death—blend with the living mind listening beside me, and it tastes like copper and rain. The last thought is not a plan of revenge, but a plea for mercy: “If you’re listening, you must carry this with care. Do not weaponize their fear. Do not let the city forget what it forgets already—the people who have died for it.” It is a call for restraint, a confession that truth, when weaponized, can kill more than lies ever could.

The revelation becomes a choice: reveal the conspiracy to the world and risk a civil war of memory, or burn the project to ash and let the truth vanish with the flames, leaving the city safer in the short term but morally bankrupt in the long run. I choose neither easy path nor grand bravado. I choose to do what the dead would want—give them their last word, but with a guardrail.

I report to the Bureau, and we publish the memorials as a catalog of last thoughts, not as evidence of guilt but as evidence of humanity’s fragility. The names of those who died in pursuit of the truth—curators, guards, scholars, ordinary citizens—are not weaponized, but archived. Marin’s network is disbanded in a way that preserves the possibility of reform; we create a different kind of Listening House, one that invites the dead to speak in controlled, ethical ways, and keeps the living from becoming puppets of memory.

The city does not become perfect after that, of course. It never does, not in a world where powers are forged in the fires of ambition and fear. But the last thoughts I hear now come less as violent cries and more as a chorus—soft, almost intimate, and occasionally hopeful. They remind me that there is wisdom in endings when they are honored rather than exploited.

I still wake to the last thoughts, and sometimes I dread them. But I have learned to listen not to extract confession, but to protect the fragile edges of truth. Some days, a single line from a dying mind runs through me and steadies my breath: a reminder that even in a world where death speaks, there can be mercy. And perhaps, in that mercy, there is a way for the living to live with the dead—not as enemies or puzzles to be solved, but as neighbors who chose to tell the truth, honestly and carefully, so that the city might learn to listen without violence.

If you ask me what I am, I will tell you I am the Listener. If you ask what I do, I will say I guard the last words of those who cannot guard themselves anymore. And if you ask what I want, I want a city where the dead are not used as weapons and the living are allowed to hear the truth without being torn apart by it. Until then, I walk the rain-soaked streets of Axiom, listening for the next last thought and choosing, with every breath, to carry it with care.

samples.prompt: One day, when you are 65 years old, you receive an email. It's a bill for every time you subscribed to a youtube channel.
samples.output:
The morning I turned sixty-five, the world felt quieter than I remembered from the weeks before the last birthday that really mattered. The kettle hissed in the kitchen, the lighthouse across the bay pulsed faintly through the blinds, and my phone pinged with its usual, tiny, unimportant reminders: a calendar notification, a weather alert, a grocery app telling me I’d forgotten garlic. Then a new email blinked into view, the screen’s blue glow catching the wrinkles at the corners of my eyes as if I’d aged into it.

Subject: Your YouTube Subscriptions Ledger — Action Required

The words looked absurdly formal for something so intimate, something that had followed me from adolescence into the quiet of retirement, something I’d never imagined would be charged back to me like a library fine I couldn’t ignore. The sender was a name I didn’t recognize, the kind of corporate syllables that sounded like a committee discussing the ethics of popcorn at a movie premiere. But the body of the email was clear, almost lyrical in its clinical precision: a bill for every time I subscribed to a YouTube channel.

I blinked at the screen, as if the bill might vanish if I refused to acknowledge it. My life flashed in the corners of my mind—schoolhouse days, the pulse of late-night lectures I’d streamed when I could no longer stay awake for a real one, the first shaky steps into adulthood when a video on “how to fix a leaky faucet” suddenly made a week’s rent feel manageable. A ledger, they called it. A record of the tiny acts I had performed with a click: a sign, a signal, a choice.

The page unfolded as if I were reading my own obituary in real time, except it wasn’t. It was a catalog of moments stitched together by an algorithm that had outlived my fear of it. The bill listed channel after channel, each with a date and a price, each price a reminder of the moment I pressed subscribe or re-subscribe after a channel had drifted into irrelevance or remained relevant enough to haunt me with its predictable reliability.

Channel after channel, I found the names I recognized and some that seemed familiar only in the way a dream identifies a place you’ve never visited but feel you’ve wandered through in sleep: “The Gentle Gardener,” “Nostalgia Arcade,” “Guitar in One Week,” “Tiny Lectures on Tiny Things,” “Cooking with Nana’s Old Oven,” and a dozen others whose titles were neither clever nor proud but somehow true to themselves. There were many more that I no longer remembered subscribing to, but the ledger did not forget. It recorded every click, every moment of curiosity borrowed and never returned.

The bill wasn’t just money; it was a map of a life spent in the float of a screen, a life that extended beyond the living room and into the hours when the house slept and the world seemed to lean closer to hear what I might learn next. The total due looked startlingly large to a person who had once counted pennies for coffee and rent and who now owned a small nest of memories rather than a bank.

I sat with the iPad on my knees, a mug of tea cooling in my hands, and I read the details aloud to myself as if the numbers could speak back in something resembling sincerity. The charges weren’t uniform. Some were tiny as a whisper, a few cents for a channel I subscribed to during a late night of restless scrolling. Others were heftier, as if the memory attached to them had suddenly become a larger piece of fabric in the quilt of my life. Acknowledging them felt both ridiculous and necessary, like admitting that you’d once believed the mailman delivered your future in a plain white envelope.

The ledger listed dates that spanned decades. There were subscriptions from years I barely recognized as mine—when I had a different name for myself, or a different set of dreams, or maybe simply the same dreams in a gathering of years that had grown thicker with time. There were channels that seemed to belong to someone younger, someone more curious about the world in broader, louder ways. And there were channels I kept past my own prime, the ones that felt like old kitchen benches: practical, comforting, stubbornly consistent even when nothing else would be.

As I skimmed, a thread of memory tugged so insistently I almost laughed aloud. I remembered the night I subscribed to a video about baking bread with my late mother’s favorite recipe—an old family loaf that had given me the sense of belonging I’d craved in a world that constantly told me to move faster. Then there was the day I subscribed to a channel that taught basic guitar chords, not because I needed to learn guitar at sixty-five, but because adolescence carried the same ache for artistry that time never quite quiets. The bill’s numbers didn’t justify the warmth those channels had given me, but they didn’t deny it, either.

The email offered a payment option: pay now, or set up a monthly installment plan with a note that read, in the careful prose of a bank that wanted to be compassionate: This is a statement of your personal economy of attention. It did not threaten consequences beyond notification, but the implied consequence—if I chose not to engage—felt heavier than any bill ever has.

I called my daughter, though I knew I would not need to. She picked up after a few rings, the sound of a car engine in the background, a city morning that sounded nothing like the one I was listening to at home.

“Hey, you found something strange in your inbox?” she asked, half-joking, half-worried.

“I found a ledger,” I said, and the word felt ceremonial on my tongue. “A bill for every time I subscribed to a channel.”

There was a silence that could have been a period, or a pause between breaths, or a moment merely waiting to become something else. Then she spoke, the familiar cadence of someone who had learned to measure life in the margins of the day rather than in the headlines of the day.

“Papa,” she teased, “this is what the internet does to time: it records every moment you lent it. It’s not a debt; it’s a diary with receipts.”

Her words sat with me, stubborn and strange and strangely comforting. A diary of attention. A diary of choices that, once made, refused to fade into mere memory. The reality of it—my own hand in the course of my life’s attention—felt simultaneously ridiculous and almost sacred. If attention were a currency, what did you spend it on? What did you gain besides a feeling of being connected to strangers across the wires?

I folded the screen into a warm silence and leaned back in the chair, the way you lean back when you’ve woken from a long dream and you realize the dream is still with you, only softening into daylight. The bill lay in the air between memory and reckoning. Some part of me wanted to ignore it; another wanted to parse it until every dot and line could tell me something I hadn’t learned about myself in years.

The day wore on with its normal rhythms—the clock ticking, the kettle singing, the fog lifting from the harbor. That evening I opened the window a little wider and allowed the cool air to borrow a corner of the room, bringing with it the faint scent of salt and distant rain. I thought about the channels that had fed me the easiest pleasures, the channels that had been the most stubborn teachers, and the channels I had subscribed to out of idle curiosity and left to fester in their own stubbornness.

In the end, I did something I hadn’t expected: I composed a reply to the ledger, not to deny the charges, but to reinterpret them. I wrote back with a pencil on a notepad, the handwriting jagged from years of long brown nights in front of a screen, the way your handwriting changes once you realize you’re no longer trying to erase tomorrow’s mistakes.

I wrote that I would accept the bill as a memory of time, not just as a debt. I would not erase the past’s appetite for learning and wonder, but I would temper it with a promise to choose where I put my attention going forward. I would unsubscribe from channels that did not feed the life I wanted to live, and I would subscribe to the ones that connected me to the people I loved most, to the places I still wanted to visit, to the work that still woke me up in the morning with a little electric charge of possibility.

If the ledger wanted payment, I would offer something more valuable than coins: presence. I would pay in time—in real days spent sitting with a grandchild who wants to learn the guitar, in mornings spent tending the small garden that has become my quiet rebellion against oblivion, in evenings when I listen to a friend’s stories about a life lived with courage and humor and the stubborn belief that there is a future worth fighting for.

The bill’s total, I realize, is less about money than about acknowledging what I did with the life that was mine to spend. The number can be intimidating, but the meaning—if you are honest with yourself—is liberating. It is a reminder that attention is a finite resource, and how we choose to use it shapes who we become when the screen goes dark and the days stretch out, unfiltered, in front of us.

So I made a small vow, printed it on the back of a page in my old notebook where I keep addresses and a few stubborn dreams: to live with intention, to monitor the channels that truly nourish the soul, to unearth the ones that drain, and to pass the lesson on to whoever still believes that a click can change a life.

When I closed the notebook and looked up, the room was different somehow, as if the act of naming the bill had altered the air around me. The sea outside kept its patient rhythm, the lamp glowed with a steadier light, and for the first time in a long while, I felt not older, but more awake.

If there is a moral to a bill of this kind, maybe it is this: when the ledger of your attention returns you a sum larger than you anticipated, do not despair. Let it teach you to spend what you have left in a way that makes the days worth counting. Let it be a reminder to live, not to accumulate. And if, in the end, the bill remains unpaid in part, perhaps that is fine—so long as you have paid with something you cannot subtract: your time, your memory, your willingness to choose again.

I haven’t paid every bit of it yet, and I don’t intend to. But I will pay with attention—carefully, lovingly, and with the full knowledge that a life well watched is not a life wasted, but a life that learns to be selective, generous, and, above all, present. And maybe, when I’m 80 and the harbor glows gold at dusk, I’ll look back and see that the real price wasn’t owed to a bill at all, but paid to the people I watched beside me, the days I watched with them, and the quiet, stubborn art of choosing what truly matters.

samples.prompt: In the future, it is discovered that people with Schizophrenia are actually telepaths. These telepaths provide the only way to send faster than light messages across the vastness of space. But in this future, an evil organization attempts to militarize them.
samples.output:
On the night they announced the discovery, the stars outside the observation deck looked the same as they did yesterday, and yesterday already felt like a secret kept too long. The press overwhelmed us with numbers and medical jargon, but the scientists spoke in a language that sounded almost like music: the discovery that people diagnosed with schizophrenia were, in fact, telepaths—a network of minds that could carry messages faster than light across the void. The implications rolled out like a new gravity: it bent technology, politics, religion, even war.

In the weeks that followed, our city learned to listen in a new way. The telepaths weren’t a disease to be cured; they were a backbone of civilization’s next leap. We didn’t glimpse telepathy as a single talent, but as a chorus of minds—some whispering, some shouting, some singing in a voice that was not quite any one person’s. The hardest truth to admit was that the first to sense it—the scientists who cataloged the phenomenon—found a familiar pattern in the brains of people labeled with schizophrenia: a pattern not of noise, but of resonance. The brain, they argued, had always been an antenna; schizophrenia was the antenna’s open channel, tuned unusually wide.

I was not a scientist, nor a doctor, nor a soldier. I was a relay operator for the Interstellar Postal Network, a job that felt ceremonial once the telepaths began to be treated as what they were: a natural, indispensable neural conduit. My own days were spent patching messages in and out of the network, translating the raw, ecstatic hum in the telepaths’ heads into a signal that ships could interpret, and sometimes into a sensation that crewmen could feel in their bones when a message arrived. It was not telepathy in the sense of “read my thoughts.” It was telepathy in the sense of “you hold a note in your brain, a note that travels at the speed of thought and lands where you intend it to, so the universe doesn’t have to wait for light to catch up.”

The first time I heard the old voices—the ones that used to terrify people, the voices that haunted the diagnosis sheets—I recognized them as something else now: carriers. They were the nodes of a vast, living network. When I closed my eyes and tuned in, the chorus rose not as static in my skull but as a harmonized field that felt like a cosmic choir singing through our heads. It was a gift and a duty: to receive and repeat, to guard and guide, to ensure that a message could cross the distance between ships and planets as surely as a ship’s hull could cut through vacuum.

But the world’s old guards did not simply step back. An organization rose from the shadows with a promise that sounded like a balm and a bludgeon at once: they called themselves The Crown, a private empire built on order, secrecy, and the blunt force of power. They claimed to be guardians of civilization, the only force capable of keeping the fragile network from tearing apart under the mass of its own power. Their plan, in the bluntest form: militarize the telepaths. Turn the choir into a weapon, bind the minds to a command more lasting and more binding than any iron or alloy. They envisaged a fleet that commands not only by code and laser, but by a synchronized mental field—an army that could reach a planet’s defense systems by simply whispering to the soldiers within.

To be clear, I do not caricature the Crown as pure evil. They wore their calculus like a suit of armor. Their argument was pragmatic: if humanity would drift into galactic space without a centralized defense, we would be shredded by pirates, insurgents, and alien intelligences that thought at durations longer than a human’s breath. The command structure of the Crown siphoned telepaths into a unit that could pace the tempo of war: mental artillery, psychic reconnaissance, and a discipline that could calm a ship’s crew or unmake it with the wrong thought at the wrong moment. They offered structure, protection, and a version of peace that looked reassuring from the outside. They also drew a hard map between “us” and “them”—the telepaths who believed the network should govern its own use, and the Crown who believed the network should be governed by those who could buy and enforce its very governance.

I saw the seeds of this conflict the moment they approached me with their proposal. They did not come to my city by rumor or rumor’s friend, the fear; they arrived in a formal invitation, promising a new role, a new life, no longer as a fragile, haunted relay, but as a soldier in a quiet, efficient machine. The terms sounded like progress, and for a dozen heartbeats I almost believed it would be. Then I felt the first tremor—the tremor of a mind choosing to break away, the tremor of the network deciding not to bend to a single will.

The resistance began with whispers and clandestine clinics, with telepaths who preferred anonymity and a chorus that preferred unity. We were not the loud thunder of war, but the soft, persistent tide: small acts of noncompliance, a refusal to submit certain thoughts to a single command, a refusal to broadcast a message when the Crown’s order came with a smile and a pin. We found each other in the quiet places—the meditation rooms of old hospitals, the hum of the shipyards at night, the forgotten corridors of space stations that still remembered how to be human.

I learned to hear the network in layers. Some layers spoke in the half-sleep of a crew’s watch, guiding pilots to keep their hands steady and their hearts clear. Some layers spoke as a heartbeat-lullaby to a family far away, a reminder that even across light-years you could still feel the right warmth of another person. And then there were the layers that hummed in cold, clinical, almost surgical tones, those the Crown tried to enforce: the calm, steady voice that could give an order and erase doubt. We learned to mute those layers, to let the network speak in textures that allowed people to think for themselves again.

The turning point came when the Crown attempted a preemptive strike: a mass concentration of telepathic will, a sweep that would have captured every mind in a sector and folded it into their own. It was the first time we saw what their power would mean in practice—the momentary silence of thousands of minds, followed by a single, monstrous thought that demanded obedience. It would have been the end of the Quiet, the end of free thought, and the end of any hope for a peaceful, humane future in space.

We did not stop them with a single act of rebellion. We did not shatter them with a heroic broadcast that could freeze a ship’s engines or scramble a captain’s nerve. We stopped them by doing what telepaths do best: listening. We found a vulnerability not in their power, but in their fear—fear that the network would choose a higher purpose than control, fear that the choir would sing something they could not dampen or drown. So we did the quiet thing: we offered the Crown a different melody, a shared one, a refrain that could include their legitimate need for order without surrendering the autonomy we all carried inside us.

We broadcast a message to every telepath in the sector, a simple line that carried through the network like a gentle echo: we are here to protect, not to dominate; we will cooperate, not compel. The Crown’s plan depended on isolating minds, on isolating people from the chorus that linked them all. Our answer was to knit the network tighter, to show them that a mind is not a fortress to be seized but a bridge to be shared.

When the Crown finally backed away, they did not leave with a roar. They retreated with something more painful than defeat: a recognition that a weapon is only as useful as the fear it is built upon, and the fear had begun to melt away. The telepaths did not become soldiers in a war they did not want; they became the custodians of a new kind of defense—one that outpaced missiles and shields because it moved through the minds of those who carried the universe inside their skulls.

The public, which had once treated schizophrenia as a pathology to be cooled, began to see it as a talent to be understood. A new era started, not with banners and rifles, but with clinics that helped telepaths harness their resonance ethically, with laws that protected them from coercive enlistment, and with a federation of worlds that agreed to trade messages across the void with consent and care, not coercion and fear.

And where did that leave me, the relay operator who learned to hear the music in the storm? I stayed at the edge of the network, a quiet conductor who kept the channels clear, who learned to listen without being commanded. Sometimes, when ships drifted into distant orbits and reports came in as tremors of thought, I could swear I heard a chorus in the background—the voices not as noise, but as a map. A map of routes, of agreements, of promises to protect the fragile, luminous thing we had built together: a galaxy connected not by force, but by the shared breath of minds that learned to listen to one another across the vastness of space.

If the universe is a place where distance erases itself, then the greatest wonder of our time is not that we discovered telepaths, but that we chose to treat them as partners, not weapons. We chose to let the choir sing, and in its harmony we found a future worth fighting for—not against one another, but together, across light-years and through the quiet, unyielding reach of the human mind.

samples.prompt: "Stop your crying! There's always someone out there who has it worse than you."
samples.output:
“Stop your crying! There’s always someone out there who has it worse than you.”

The words arrived like a spoon in a dish I hadn’t finished chewing through. They came from the kitchen, from the person who should have handed me a napkin and a listen, not a verdict. The room had the dull light of a winter evening—hangnails of shadow along the edge of the countertop, the buzz of the fridge somewhere in the next room—and yet the line stretched out, a taut wire I felt more than heard.

I was eight or nine, maybe ten, sitting on the edge of our dented kitchen chair, knees pulled to my chest, the world outside the window a blur of gray and rain. The thing I’d cried about—whatever it was in that moment, some scraped knee or a loneliness that felt too big for a small body—didn’t matter to the person delivering the sentence. What mattered was that emotions were a hazard, something to be contained, smoothed away, measured against some unknowable ledger of “worse” and “better.”

In that memory, as in many others, the phrase lands with a peculiar double hit: a sting of invalidation and a perilous logic that makes you want to apologize for existing. If there’s always someone worse off, then your own ache must be a petty misalignment in the universe. Your tears become a misfiled page in a book that’s supposed to be about resilience, about grit, about the stubborn refusal to fall apart.

As an adult, I learned to recognize that line in other voices, too. Friendships that pretend they’re offering perspective while they’re really offering a shield. A partner who says, “I’m glad you’re upset, but you know—people have it worse.” A coworker who reveals a glimmer of judgment behind the sympathy: “I cried in the meeting once, but I got over it; you should try to do the same.” Even strangers on social media who scatter the same insinuation like bread crumbs: you should count your blessings, you should stop whining, you should be grateful for the life you have and stop imagining it could be more than that.

The problem with the line isn’t merely the invalidation it performs in the moment; it’s the gravity it lends to a universal complaint: pain is a finite resource and should be conserved for the truly afflicted. If someone else has it worse, then your own hurt is less significant, less real, less in need of company and care. And the more you internalize that gravity, the less you trust your own experience of suffering. You learn to quantify your grief the way you quantify calories, always with the reminder that someone else has already logged a bigger number. It isn’t that the world is full of bad people; it’s that the idea of comparative suffering travels easily under the doorframe of kindness and becomes a tool for survival rather than a route to understanding.

I’ve learned, too, that there’s a paradox here: acknowledging that others suffer in ways you cannot grasp is an act of decency, not a reason to silence your own cries. It’s possible to hold two truths at once: that there is real and cruel pain in the world beyond your own door, and that your pain matters, that it has a claim on your attention and the attention of another human being. The problem arises when we use the first truth as a weapon against the second.

There are moments, in hospital corridors or in the dim hours after a break-up, when someone does stop to listen. A pause that feels almost reverent, a chair drawn closer, a voice that doesn’t hurry to silence. In those moments, I’ve heard a gentler version of the same message: your feelings are legitimate; you’re allowed to feel them; I’m here with you. The difference is not that the second message denies suffering, but that it refuses to turn pain into a contest. It reframes the experience as a shared human vulnerability rather than a misweighed ledger entry.

I’ve also learned the language of self-compassion, which doesn’t require you to pretend your pain is the worst or the best, or to pretend your life is a flawless, untroubled road. It’s the language of small, honest steps: naming what you feel, even when the words tremble, letting yourself be still when your body wants to run, asking for help when the weight feels too heavy to bear alone. It’s a practice of staying, even when staying hurts, for a little longer than would be comfortable, until someone else’s listening ear slides into place and makes a little room for your ache.

In fiction and in real life, the line surfaces again and again. In a story, a character cries on a park bench after a bad day, and a stranger sits beside them and says nothing at first—only breathes with them, as if to say, you are not a burden to be shouldered alone. In real life, you might be in a girl’s bathroom with water-streaked cheeks, or in a car parked by a river, or on a couch whose cushions have remembered the shape of your grief better than your own body has. In those spaces, the same impulse to minimize can reappear, masked as humor or pointed observation. It’s not always malicious; sometimes it’s a tired reflex, a rule learned in childhood: “Be quiet about the things that make others uncomfortable.”

I’ve tried to replace that reflex, as best I can, with another habit: asking permission to stay with the feeling. It’s a simple question, but it resets the room: “Are you okay if I sit with you for a moment?” or “Would you like to tell me what’s making you cry, or would you rather I just sit here until you’re ready?” The shift is nonverbal as much as verbal. It gives the other person agency—an antidote to the impulse to fix or dismiss. And it teaches a counterdiscipline to that ancestral phrase: you don’t have to measure pain in the same unit as someone else’s. You only have to acknowledge it as real.

There remains the ache of memory—the little kitchen where that line was first hurled at me, the faces that used to shape how I thought about my own feelings. It’s not about erasing the past. It’s about letting the past lose its power to silence the person I am becoming. If someone cries, it doesn’t mean they owe the world an accounting of their sorrows. It means they deserve a moment of presence. If someone shares a grievance or a wound, it isn’t the time to tally lives and assign a moral score. It’s the time to listen without surrendering the truth of one’s own pain, and to offer a hand or a shoulder or a space for breath.

The prompt—Stop your crying! There’s always someone out there who has it worse than you—remains a stubborn echo in my memory, a phrase that travels through time like a brittle blade. It’s not a wisdom so much as a reminder of a pull we all feel: to compare, to judge, to soothe ourselves by diminishing what others feel. But if we listen with care, we learn that the most radical act isn’t to pretend others have it worse but to recognize that our own wet cheeks, our own tremors, are worthy of notice, worthy of patience, worthy of connection.

So I tell myself, and I tell others who feel the sting of that line, that feelings aren’t a competition but a shared experience. If you ever find yourself on the receiving end of those words, give yourself the space to grieve—in whatever form your heart asks for. If you’re the one who needs to hear a different answer, offer it: a steady voice, a hand held a little longer, a promise to stay, even when staying hurts. The world, after all, is full of people who carry more than their daily load and still carry you, if you let them. And sometimes, the most generous thing you can do for another person—and for yourself—is to listen without ranking the pain, to sit with the crying, and to remind each other that being human is enough, that feeling is valid, and that you are not alone in your ache.

samples.prompt: Write an emotionally devastating three word story.
samples.output:
Three words can be a door slammed in a room full of memories. A three-word story is not shy about what it wants to do: it thrusts you into a moment of truth, then leaves you to fill in the rest with your own wounds and histories. It is a form that refuses to spell out the sentence that should come after, because the sentence that follows is a supposition, a guess, a confession you already know how to make, if you’ve ever loved or lost. An emotionally devastating three-word story is, in its brevity, a soundless scream—heard not by the mouth that speaks it, but by the heart that reads it.

Crafting such a piece requires a peculiar balance. Each word must carry more weight than it seems capable of supporting; each silence between words must become a room you can walk through, a corridor that widens as you step into it. The first word can name the befalling event—the departure, the illness, the failure—without needing to narrate the entire history. The second word anchors the witness, the speaker, or the world that holds or refuses to hold them. The third word closes like a lid, or opens into a whisper that won’t quiet down. The trick is to choose verbs and nouns that imply vast consequences without spelling them out, so the reader’s own memory supplies the bulk of the pain. A three-word story is not a summary; it is a hinge, a door left slightly ajar, a memory remembered at high speed.

Here are a handful of three-word stories that ache when you read them aloud, and why they ache:

Gone before dawn.
The line implies a disappearance that happened in the night, a presence that evaporates into the morning air. It could describe a lover, a child, a life once lived, or an opportunity that slipped away too early to be called by its rightful name. The devastation sits in the unspoken question: what did dawn illuminate that dawn did not bring back? The reader fills in the gaps with fear and longing—the person who vanished, the life not lived, the sound of a door closing behind something irreplaceable.

We were alone.
This is a portrait of shared solitude, a micro-history of two souls who thought they walked the same path but discover the pavement is empty beneath their feet. The word “we” binds, while “alone” isolates. The devastation is communal and intimate at once: the memory of togetherness that no longer exists, the moment when two become one story and then later suddenly two separate stories with parallel heartbreaks. The power is in the paradox of connection that has extinguished.

Everything changed yesterday.
Time confesses in this line. The phrase implies an abrupt, irreversible pivot, a hinge that swings with a single, decisive impulse. Yesterday is the boundary between what was and what is, between a previous future and a present that feels foreign. The devastation lies in the suddenness—the past cannot contain the present; the person who woke up yesterday is still the same person, except not at all. The readers supply the memory of the catastrophe: an accident, a revelation, a betrayal, or a realization that makes all past days appear differently colored and suddenly untrustworthy.

Time stopped yesterday.
Similar in structure but different in mood, this line uses time as the enemy and the confidant. It suggests a moment frozen, a life paused in mid-breath, a heartbeat that refused to continue in the line it had been following. The emotional ache is the denial of progress—the sense that forward motion is the weight of grief, and the day that should have pushed us ahead refused to cooperate. The reader conjures the scene: a kiss that never landed, a phone that never rang, a decision that never first could be made.

I burned it.
This line circles the ruin of memory or possibility. The “it” can be anything: a letter, a photograph, a vow, a future plan. The act of burning is final, but the aftermath is slow and haunted. The devastation comes not from the physical act alone but from what remains unsaid—the thing you wanted to preserve is now ash, and in the ashes lives the guilt, the relief, the reckoning, all tangled. The reader feels complicit, even if not literally responsible, because burning is a ritual that asks: what would you burn to keep yourself intact?

She never came.
A sentence that begins as a simple report and ends as an indictment. It can apply to a lover who never arrived at the promised rendezvous, a parent who missed a child’s life, a call that never reached. The pain comes from absence, and from the assumption that intention was a lie, or at least unreliable. The waiting is the cruelty; the eventual realization that the expected presence never materialized. The line lingers in the memory of every doorstep, every missed graduation, every quiet room that hasn’t recovered from the sound of a timer that never reached the last bell.

Your memory lingers.
This one is more contemplative, and yet it aches with an ache that won’t quit. It recognizes the stubborn endurance of memory—the way a face, a scent, a phrase can keep returning at the most inconvenient times. The devastation isn’t always about a single event; sometimes it’s the long geology of grief, the way a life’s texture remains visible under the skin of the present. The line is a confession that the past refuses to stay buried, that memory can be a blessing and a weapon, both at once.

You left me.
Direct, accusatory, intimate. The three words perform a dual act: they names the act (leaving) and the affected, wounded self (me). The devastation is personal and relational: a rupture that cannot be repaired by dialogue, a wound that cannot be soothed by time. The line invites the reader to feel the gravity of abandonment—how power shifts in the moment someone walks away, and how the space they leave behind can fill with echoes that never fully quiet.

I am not here.
A line of stark existential reckoning. The three words strip away performance and pose the simplest question of all: who remains when we vanish from a room? The heartbreak is not only about others’ absence but about the self’s potential erasure. It is a reminder that visibility matters as much as being present; the fear of becoming a shadow is a fear many have carried into the quiet hours of night.

How to write your own devastating three-word story
- Pick a hinge moment. The three words should sit at the edge of a memory or a revelation—a moment when a life could be reconsidered in a different light. Think of a turning point, not a constant state.
- Let implication carry weight. The goal is not to tell everything but to invite the reader to lean in, to complete the sentence with their own experience.
- Choose pronouns that evoke a relationship. “We,” “you,” “I”—these voices compress distance and closeness at the same time.
- Favor verbs that carry gravity. A simple verb with the right noun can feel explosive—stopped, burned, left, vanished, believed.
- Embrace ambiguity. A line that could be interpreted in several ways allows memory to do some of the heavy lifting, which is where suffering often resides.
- Balance tense and timing. Past, present, or a mix can shift the emotional color of the line, making the moment feel immediate or forever delayed.

A short practice exercise
Write ten three-word lines without context. Then pick one you feel most drawn to, and write a paragraph that imagines the scene behind it. Don’t build a plot, just sketch the mood, the stakes, the possible backstory that the line already implies. Notice how the same word placed differently can soften or sharpen the pain.

If you’re searching for that exact moment of devastation, you’ll find it not in a grand confession but in a few carefully chosen particles—the name of a person, the closeness that used to be, the abrupt end of a promise. The power of a three-word story is that it can stage the entire catastrophe in the mere space of a breath, and then let the reader live with the aftershocks for longer than it took to utter the line.

In the end, an emotionally devastating three-word story isn’t a tragedy in isolation; it’s a memory in motion. It asks you to remember what you have lost, but to keep reading long enough to figure out what you still hold and what, perhaps, you can still become. If you write truthfully, those three words will ring in the reader’s ear long after the page is turned, a quiet, stubborn ache that says: the story isn’t over, not while there is still room for longing.

samples.prompt: A man jokingly shows a silver back gorilla at the zoo google images of female gorillas. To everyone’s surprise he gestures for more pictures. Suddenly he gestures for the man to stop. He sees an image of the female he is looking for, and he knows where to find her.
samples.output:
The zoo is crowded with laughter and the thrum of summer. A man with a widow’s peak and a jacket that’s seen better days stands before the silverback enclosure, phone in one hand, a swagger in his shoulders that says he’s about to make a joke the crowd can’t ignore. He tilts the screen toward his friend, as if the glass between them keeps the punchline from ever landing wrong. Then he taps, and a collage erupts: Google Images, a chorus of glossy fur and almond eyes, all labeled “female gorilla.” The crowd blinks, bemused, and someone whistles—half admiration, half disbelief—that he’s actually using the moment to play.

“See? This is what we call science,” he jokes, though the science here is mostly silliness. The page settles on one image after another, a procession of black-and-gold silhouettes and the soft blur of fur. He scrolls, and the gorilla behind the glass stares back with a gaze that seems uncomfortably alert, as if he’s watching a human trying to pet him with a better joke.

“More pictures?” he asks, and the crowd erupts with a chorus of “One more! One more!” The man grins, but there’s something in the way his fingers hover over the next thumbnail that betrays more curiosity than comedy. He taps again, and the display multiplies into a spiderweb of gorilla forms, a gallery of potential mates, of different postures and poses, as if the animals themselves were modeling a portfolio.

Then the mood shifts as if a curtain slipped and weighed down the air. The gorilla in the enclosure—his silver-back, broad as a doorway and patient as a storm—beats his chest in a rhythm that has nothing to do with humor and everything to do with presence. It’s not a performance now; it’s a language. The people around him murmur, and the man notices the way the gorilla’s eyes fix on a particular corner of the crowd, on a figure who is not there to pose but to observe.

The gorilla’s gaze pivots toward the man, toward the phone, toward the stream of images still scrolling on screen. Then, almost as if the animal understands the human impulse behind all this — the longing to see something more than a face on a screen — the gorilla does something uncanny. He lifts his forearm and, with a slow, deliberate gesture, points his finger—an odd, human gesture—toward a pair of visitors. It could be nothing, but the air tightens, the laughter tightens, and the man feels a pull toward the moment.

“Stop,” he says to the crowd, not loud, not offended, just suddenly aware of the weight of what’s happening. People pause. The laughter dies into a soft, anticipatory hum. The gorilla’s chest settles, as if satisfied the message has landed. In the quiet, the man glances back at his phone. A new arrangement of images sits there, not random thumbnails but one square among many that seems to pull on something deeper than humor.

The image is of a woman—the same woman he has been trying to find, though he never quite admitted that aloud to himself. It’s a face he thought he’d long forgotten, or perhaps never believed he’d see again: Lena, a photographer who once spent months in the margins of his life, chasing light and gorillas and half-remembered conversations. He recognizes her from a recent post she made, a candid by a riverbank with a scarf that flashes a scarlet thread against muted greens. It’s not just her face; it’s the context—the way she stands with a field camera slung over her shoulder, the way she seems to belong to the animal world as if she’s always listening for a different kind of whisper.

Within the image, Lena is not where he is, and yet the image calls him to a place he’s walked before: the zoo’s central path, where a long line of banners lists upcoming conservation talks and where the staff often gather at the end of the day near the rainforest corridor. It’s a place that has always felt like a hinge between past and present—a place where he could pretend to forget what he’s lost, or pretend to finally know what to do about it.

He doesn’t pretend to understand the gorilla’s odd summons, but he feels compelled to follow it. He studies the photo again, the scarf, the stance, the light catching Lena’s hair in a way that makes him believe this is not just a clue but a beacon. The gorilla has not shown him how to stalk or scheme; he’s given him something closer to a map—an image that tells him where to be when, and perhaps with whom.

“Is she… here?” his friend asks, stepping closer, half amused, half quietly alarmed by the sudden gravity in the other man’s face.

The crowd streams forward and the moment to kiss the joke goodbye grows thick with possibility. He walks toward the river path and the rainforest corridor, eyes on the image that has become a compass. The zoo’s hum rolls around him, a chorus of yelps from children, the soft rustle of leaves, the distant clucking of birds, the telltale clatter of a carelessly left coin on a bench. He moves with a careful urgency, not wanting to rush Lena if she’s there for a reason larger than a simple encounter, not wanting to frighten her if she’s not ready to be found.

And then, just where the path curves toward the observation deck, he spots her: Lena. Not in the image’s frame exactly, but in the living version of it. She’s adjusting a lens, crouched near a bench, hands steady, a look of quiet concentration that makes the world recede until all that remains is the rhythmic click of a shutter, the soft hiss of her breath, and the way her hair falls against the scarf the color of a late evening ember.

She looks up then, at last, and their eyes meet as if the years have collapsed into one quiet, unanswerable moment. Behind her, the gorilla enclosure glows with the afternoon sun, and the silverback’s shadow pools between them like a graceful omen. Lena’s lips rise in a small, surprised smile—a mix of welcome and curiosity that says she’s ready to listen, if the story they share is still theirs to tell.

He doesn’t rush. He doesn’t shove a phone in her face or recite some prepared monologue about how he found her and why this matters. He steps closer, stops a respectful distance away, and lets the image in his pocket—whatever it has revealed, whatever it has saved him from—do the talking. Lena sets her camera down and angles her body toward him, the rest of the zoo’s noise becoming a soft, almost decorative fringe.

“We’ve got a thing for gorillas in common,” she says, half joking, half serious, the way people do when they’re not sure what comes next but want to tilt the odds toward something honest.

“Maybe we just needed a better guide than a screen,” he replies, letting the thought land between them like the gentle thud of a rain drop on a broad leaf. The silverback, somewhere behind, exhales in a way that makes the entire scene feel larger than two people on a bench.

They talk, not about the chase or the chase’s end, but about what drew them here in the first place: the language of care, the quiet rituals of observation, the way a single image can become a doorway to someone’s life. Lena explains how the river path is a route she’s mapped for a forthcoming project, how the gorillas’ behavior has taught her something about patience, about letting the world reveal its own story rather than forcing one’s own. He listens, and his own story slides into place like a puzzle piece sliding home after a long search.

The gorilla’s sign-off—an unforced, almost affectionate gaze in their direction—feels less like a message to be deciphered and more like a blessing: a reminder that some connections arrive not as conquest but as a coincidence that refuses to be ignored.

When they finally stand to leave, the crowd here and there dissolves into the day’s ordinary rhythm. The man pockets the phone, his finger no longer itching to pull up more images, his heart no longer counting the steps he must take to reach someone. Lena squeezes his forearm, a small, quiet permission to stay in the moment rather than rush toward a conclusion. The gorilla’s presence lingers in the memory as a reminder that the world speaks in many dialects—some through a gaze, some through a gesture, some through the patient, stubborn discipline of a creature who has watched people and nature converge and diverge for longer than either of them has likely admitted.

They walk back toward the zoo’s core, where the crowd’s chorus swells again with the everyday noise of a city that never fully stops listening. The man—this man who started by treating a silverback as a joke—knows where to find her not because of a clue he extracted from a phone screen, but because a moment of shared awe created a path between two strangers who, for a few breaths, trusted the same thing: that a gaze may be enough to guide a life.

And if the gorilla had a way of keeping score, it would probably tally not the number of pictures viewed or the jokes told, but the quiet, unspoken agreement that sometimes the right direction is found when you look up from the screen, listen, and follow a gesture that asks you to stop, listen, and find the person you’ve been searching for in the place where life itself begins to speak in a language you can finally understand.

samples.prompt: Nobody expected the Paladin to become the evil ruler in the prophecy, and the Necromancer to become the chosen hero.
samples.output:
Nobody expected the prophecy to turn like this. The scrolls in the Tower of Veritas were written to guide, to steady fear with a map of fate. They claimed to tell who would rise and who would fall, and the names within those pages—Paladin, Neo-Torches, Necromancer—were meant to be stained in light, not inked in doubt. Yet the city of Austerhollow woke to a different truth: the Paladin was cast as the evil ruler in the prophecy, and the Necromancer as the chosen hero. The words did not lie; the people did, by reading them through the lens of fear, pride, and convenience.

The Paladin’s name was Sir Calderon, though most called him simply the Shield. He wore a white cape that showed every smudge of ash and blood, a symbol of mercy that looked more like judgment when the market stalls started selling fear as a bill of goods. Calderon had earned his belt of banners by crackling through brigand camps with the righteous fury of a man who believed he could cut away corruption with a single, clean strike. He spoke of crime as a disease, and he spoke of cleansing as a cure. He believed in law as an instrument of salvation, though protectors often become jailers when power learns to love its own reflection.
